CERTIFICATION
      We, Matthew March, Mayor, and Mary Snyder, Clerk-Treasurer, pursuant to
Ohio Revised Code 731.23 and 731.42, hereby certify that the general and
permanent legislation of the Village of Valley View, Ohio, as revised,
arranged, compiled, numbered, codified and printed herewith in component codes,
is correctly set forth and constitutes the Codified Ordinances of Valley View,
Ohio, 1975, complete to September 10, 2024.
                        /s/   Matthew March
                           Mayor
                        /s/   Mary Snyder
                           Clerk-Treasurer

COMPARATIVE SECTION TABLE
EDITOR'S NOTE: Source material for the 1975 Codified Ordinances of Valley View
was ordinances or resolutions enacted by Council or new matter ordained by the
Adopting Ordinance. Sections and subsections of the 1975 Codified Ordinances
without a history or with the words Adopting Ordinance at the end thereof are
new matter ordained by the Adopting Ordinance. In the following table the
disposition of all source material in the 1975 Valley View Codified Ordinances
is indicated.

TABLES OF SPECIAL ORDINANCES
   The Codified Ordinances of Valley View comprises all ordinances and
resolutions of a general and permanent nature. The provisions of such general
and permanent ordinances and resolutions are set forth in full in the Codified
Ordinances.
   References must be made frequently to many special ordinances and
resolutions, particularly those relating to property, such as easements,
vacations, dedications, plat approvals, acquisitions, disposals, leases, etc.
In the following Tables A through G, all such ordinances and resolutions are
listed. These Tables list ordinances and resolutions chronologically by
subject, and include both a citation to and brief description of each ordinance
and resolution.
         
TABLE A - Franchises
         
TABLE B - Easements
         
TABLE C - Vacating of Streets and Alleys
         
TABLE D - Dedication and Plat Approval
         
TABLE E - Acquisition and Disposal of Real Property
            
TABLE F - Lease of Real Property
         
TABLE G - Grade Levels and Change of Street Name

606.06
202.01 DESIGNATION; CITATION; HEADINGS.
   This volume consists of all ordinances and resolutions of a permanent and
general nature of the Municipality, revised, codified, arranged, numbered and
consolidated into component codes, titles, chapters and sections, and as such
shall be known and may be designated as the Codified Ordinances of Valley View,
Ohio, 1975, for which designation "Codified Ordinances" may be substituted.
Code, title, chapter and section headings do not constitute any part of the law
as contained in the Codified Ordinances.
(ORC 1.01)
202.02 GENERAL DEFINITIONS.
   As used in the Model Ohio Municipal Code, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   (a)   "And" may be read "or", and "or" may be read "and", if the sense
requires it.
   (b)   "Another," when used to designate the owner of property which is the
subject of an offense, includes not only natural persons but also every other
owner of property.
   (c)   "Bond" includes an undertaking.
   (d)   "Child" includes child by adoption.
   (e)   "Council" means the legislative authority of the Municipality.
   (f)   "County" means Cuyahoga County, Ohio.
   (g)   "Fire Chief" shall include the Chief of the Fire Department if such
Fire Department has been established in the Municipality, and shall include the
Fire Prevention Officer if no Fire Department has been established in the
Municipality.
   (h)   "Imprisoned" shall have the same meaning as in Ohio R.C. 1.05.
   (i)   "Internet" means the international computer network of both federal
and non-federal interoperable packet switched data networks, including the
graphical subnetwork known as the world wide web.
   (j)   "Keeper" or "proprietor" includes all persons, whether acting by
themselves or as a servant, agent, or employee.
   (k)   "Land" or "real estate" includes rights and easements of incorporeal
nature.
   (l)   "Legislative authority" means the legislative authority of the
Municipality.
   (m)   "May" is permissive.
   (n)   "Municipality" or "Village," means Valley View, Ohio.
   (o)   "OAC" refers to the Ohio Administrative Code.
   (p)   "Oath" includes affirmation; and "swear" includes affirm.
   (q)   “Of unsound mind.” The person lacks the relevant mental capacity.
   (r)   “Ohio R.C.,” “ORC” or “Revised Code” refers to the Ohio Revised Code.
   (s)   “Owner,” when applied to property, includes any part owner, joint
owner, or tenant in common of the whole or part of such property.
   (t)   “Person” includes an individual, corporation, business trust, estate,
trust, partnership, and association.
   (u)   “Personal property” includes all property except real property.
   (v)   “Plan of sewerage,” “system of sewerage,” “sewer,” and “sewers”
includes sewers, sewage disposal works and treatment plants, and sewage pumping
stations, together with facilities and appurtenances necessary and proper
therefor.
   (w)   “Premises,” as applied to property, includes land and buildings.
   (x)   “Property” includes real, personal, mixed estates, and interests.
   (y)   “Public authority” includes boards of education; the Municipal,
County, State, or Federal government, its officers, or an agency thereof; or
any duly authorized public official.
   (z)   “Public place” includes any street, sidewalk, park, cemetery, school
yard, body of water or watercourse, public conveyance, or any other place for
the sale of merchandise, public accommodation, or amusement.
   (aa)   “Real property” includes lands, tenements, and hereditaments.
   (bb)   “Registered mail” includes certified mail; and “certified mail”
includes registered mail.
   (cc)   “Shall” is mandatory.
   (dd)   “Sidewalk” means that portion of the street between the curb line and
the adjacent property line intended for the use of pedestrians.
   (ee)   “State” means the State of Ohio.
   (ff)   “Street” includes alleys, avenues, boulevards, lanes, roads,
highways, viaducts, and all other public thoroughfares within the Municipality.
   (gg)   “Tenant” or “occupant,” as applied to premises, includes any person
holding a written or oral lease, or who actually occupies the whole or any part
of such premises, alone or with others.
   (hh)   “Undertaking” includes a bond.
   (ii)   “Week” means seven consecutive days.
   (jj)   “Whoever”includes all persons, natural and artificial; partners;
principals, agents, and employees; and all officials, public or private.
   (kk)   “Writing” includes printing.
   (ll)   “Written” or in “writing” include any representation of words,
letters, symbols, or figures; this provision does not affect any law relating
to signatures.
   (mm)   “Year” means twelve consecutive months.
(ORC 1.02, 1.05, 1.44, 1.59, 701.01)
202.03 RULES OF CONSTRUCTION.
   (a)   Common and Technical Use. Words and phrases shall be read in context
and construed according to the rules of grammar and common usage. Words and
phrases that have acquired a technical or particular meaning, whether by
legislative definition or otherwise, shall be construed accordingly.
(ORC 1.42)
   (b)   Singular and Plural; Gender; Tense. As used in this Model Ohio
Municipal Code, unless the context otherwise requires:
      (1)   The singular includes the plural, and the plural includes the
singular.
      (2)   Words of one gender include the other genders.
      (3)   Words in the present tense include the future tense.
(ORC 1.43)
   (c)   Computation of Time.
      (1)   The time within which an act is required by law to be done shall be
computed by excluding the first and including the last day; except that when
the last day falls on Sunday or a legal holiday, then the act may be done on
the next succeeding day that is not a Sunday or a legal holiday.
      (2)   When a public office, in which an act required by law is to be
performed, is closed to the public for the entire day that constitutes the last
day for doing the act or before its usual closing time on that day, the act may
be performed on the next succeeding day that is not a Sunday or a legal
holiday.
      (3)   "Legal holiday," as used in divisions (c)(1) and (c)(2) of this
section, means the following days:
         A.   The first day of January, known as New Year's day;
         B.   The third Monday in January, known as Martin Luther King day;
         C.   The third Monday in February, known as Washington-Lincoln day;
         D.   The day designated in the “Act of June 28, 1968,” 82 Stat. 250, 5
U.S.C. 6103, as amended, for the commemoration of Memorial day;
         E.   The nineteenth day of June, known as Juneteenth day;
         F.   The fourth day of July, known as Independence day;
         G.   The first Monday in September, known as Labor day;
         H.   The second Monday in October, known as Columbus day;
         I.   The eleventh day of November, known as Veteran’s day;
         J.   The fourth Thursday in November, known as Thanksgiving day;
         K.   The twenty-fifth day of December, known as Christmas day;
         L.   Any day appointed and recommended by the Governor of this State
or the President of the United States as a holiday.
      (4)   If any day designated in this section as a legal holiday falls on a
Sunday, the next succeeding day is a legal holiday.
(ORC 1.14)
      (5)   When an act is to take effect or become operative from and after a
day named, no part of that day shall be included. If priority of legal rights
depends upon the order of events on the same day, such priority shall be
determined by the times in the day at which they respectively occurred.
(ORC 1.15)
      (6)   If a number of months is to be computed by counting the months from
a particular day, the period ends on the same numerical day in the concluding
month as the day of the month from which the computation is begun, unless there
are not that many days in the concluding month, in which case the period ends
on the last day of that month.
(ORC 1.45)
202.04 REVIVOR; EFFECT OF RE-ENACTMENT, AMENDMENT OR REPEAL.
   (a)   The repeal of a repealing provision of this Model Ohio Municipal Code
does not revive the provision originally repealed nor impair the effect of any
saving clause therein.
(ORC 1.57)
   (b)   The re-enactment, amendment, or repeal of this Model Ohio Municipal
Code does not, except as provided in division (c) of this section:
      (1)   Affect the prior operation of the provision or any prior action
taken thereunder.
      (2)   Affect any validation, cure, right, privilege, obligation, or
liability previously acquired, accrued, accorded, or incurred thereunder.
      (3)   Affect any violation thereof or penalty, forfeiture, or punishment
incurred in respect thereto, prior to the amendment or repeal.
      (4)   Affect any investigation, proceeding, or remedy in respect of any
privilege, obligation, liability, penalty, forfeiture, or punishment; and the
investigation, proceeding, or remedy may be instituted, continued, or enforced,
and the penalty, forfeiture, or punishment imposed, as if the provision had not
been repealed or amended.
   (c)   If the penalty, forfeiture, or punishment for any offense is reduced
by a re-enactment or amendment of this Model Ohio Municipal Code, the penalty,
forfeiture, or punishment, if not already imposed, shall be imposed according
to this Model Ohio Municipal Code as amended.
(ORC 1.58)
202.05 CONSTRUCTION OF SECTION REFERENCES.
   (a)   Wherever in a penalty section reference is made to a violation of a
section or an inclusive group of sections, or of divisions or subdivisions of a
section, such reference shall be construed to mean a violation of any provision
of the section, sections, divisions or subdivisions included in the reference.
   (b)   References in this Model Ohio Municipal Code to action taken or
authorized under designated sections of this Model Ohio Municipal Code include,
in every case, action taken or authorized under the applicable legislative
provision which is superseded by this Model Ohio Municipal Code.
(ORC 1.23)
   (c)   Whenever in one section reference is made to another section hereof,
the reference shall extend and apply to the section referred to as subsequently
amended, revised, recodified, or renumbered, unless the subject matter be
changed or materially altered by the amendment or revision.
(ORC 1.55)
202.06 CONFLICT OF LAWS.
    If the provisions of different codes, chapters or sections of the Codified
Ordinances conflict with or contravene each other, the provisions bearing the
latest passage date shall prevail. If the conflicting provisions bear the same
passage date, the conflict shall be construed so as to be consistent with the
meaning or legal effect of the subject matter taken as a whole.
202.07 SEPARABILITY.
   If any provisions of a section of this Model Ohio Municipal Code or the
application thereof to any person or circumstance is held invalid, the
invalidity does not affect other provisions or applications of the section or
related sections which can be given effect without the invalid provision or
application, and to this end the provisions are severable.
(ORC 1.50)
202.99 GENERAL PENALTY.
   Whenever, in the Codified Ordinances or in any ordinance of the
Municipality, any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an
offense or a misdemeanor, or whenever the doing of any act is required or the
failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, the commission or performance
of such act, or the failure to commit or perform such act, as required, shall,
unless another penalty is provided, be deemed a minor misdemeanor and the
offender shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each
offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during or on
which a violation or noncompliance occurs or continues, unless otherwise
provided.
CHAPTER 204
Official Standards
EDITOR'S NOTE: The State of Ohio operates on Eastern Daylight Savings Time from
2:00 a.m. of the first Sunday in April until 2:00 a.m. of the last Sunday in
October. Congress, on March 22, 1966, passed the Uniform Time Act requiring
uniform observance throughout the nation of Daylight Savings Time starting in
1967, except that a State legislature could exempt the entire state from
Daylight Savings Time or divide a state into not more than two parts, each with
a different time standard. The Ohio legislature, through inaction, has elected
to observe Eastern Daylight Savings Time throughout the State.
   On August 8, 2005, the Energy Policy Act of 2005 was enacted. This Act
changed the time change dates for Daylight Saving Time in the United States.
Beginning in 2007, the State of Ohio begins Daylight Saving Time at 2:00 a.m.
on the second Sunday in March and reverts to standard time at 2:00 a.m. on the
first Sunday in November. The Secretary of Energy will report the impact of
this change to Congress. Congress retains the right to resume the 2005 Daylight
Saving Time schedule once the Department of Energy study is complete.
   There are no sections in
Chapter 204. This chapter has been established to provide a place for cross
references and any future legislation.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   State standard of time - see Ohio R.C. 1.04
   State legal holidays - see Ohio R.C. 1.14, 5.20 et seq.
   State flag - see Ohio R.C. 5.01

660.21
206.01 PUBLIC MEETINGS.
    Unless otherwise provided by law, all meetings of Council and its regular
and special committees, of all commissions, boards and advisory committees to
Council, and all other public bodies of the Village, shall be held at the
Village Hall.
   All meetings of the aforesaid public bodies shall be open to attendance by
the public unless an executive session is expressly authorized by law. Nothing
herein contained shall require that any public body permit public participation
in such open meeting unless specifically required by law.
(Ord. 75-11-2. Passed 12-2-75.)
206.02 NOTIFICATION OF MEETINGS.
   (a)   The date, time and place of all regular meetings of any of the public
bodies referred to in Section
206.01 shall be noted in a calendar of monthly meetings, which calendar shall
be posted by the Clerk of the Village on the notice board outside of the
Village Hall not later than five calendar days prior to the first day of the
month in which such meetings will be held.
   (b)   The date, time, place and purpose of any special meeting of any of the
public bodies referred to in Section
206.01 shall be provided to any news media by the Clerk not later than twenty-
four hours prior to the scheduled starting time of such meeting.
   (c)   In the event of an emergency meeting of any of the public bodies
referred to in Section
206.01, the Clerk shall communicate the date, time, place and purpose of such
meeting to the news media that have requested such notification.
   (d)   Any news media desiring notification shall make such a request, in
writing, upon an appropriate letterhead, to the Clerk. Council, or the Clerk,
may from time to time request that updated letters of notification be filed by
the news media. All such requests shall be filed by the Clerk and shall be a
matter of public record.
   (e)   Any person, organization or group of persons is entitled to mail
notice of the calendar of monthly meetings. To obtain this notice, such persons
are required to fill out a form provided by the Clerk for such purposes and
shall pay a fee of one dollar ($1. 00) per calendar requested. It shall
thereafter be the duty of the Clerk to provide such notice. All such requests
shall be filed by the Clerk and shall be a matter of public record.
   (f)   Any requesting person, organization or group of persons shall receive
advance notice of all meetings at which any specific type of public business
will be discussed and/or acted upon. To obtain this notice, such persons are
required to fill out a form provided by the Clerk for such purposes and shall
pay a fee of one dollar ($1.00) per notification. It shall thereafter be the
duty of the Clerk to provide such notice. All such requests shall be filed by
the Clerk and shall be a matter of public record.
   (g)   The notifications required under this section shall be in addition to
any and all other notice requirements provided by law.
(Ord. 75-11-2. Passed 12-2-75.)
206.03 MINUTES OF MEETINGS.
   (a)   Subsequent to their approval, the minutes of all public bodies
referred to in Section
206.01 shall be open to the public for inspection. Minutes of executive
sessions of public bodies need only reflect the general subject matter of
discussion in such executive session.
   (b)   The Clerk of the Village shall keep a Minute Book for each public
body. The Minute Books shall contain the approved minutes of all meetings of
each public body. The public may inspect the Minute Books at all reasonable
times.
(Ord. 75-11-2. Passed 12-2-75.)

220.01 REGULAR AND SPECIAL MEETINGS; WORKSHOPS.
   (a)   Regular Meetings. The Council shall hold regular meetings on the first
Tuesday of each month at precisely 6:30 p.m., unless otherwise provided by
Council. Prior to the start of a regular meeting, the Finance Committee shall
meet at 6:00 p.m. followed by a Caucus at 6:15 p.m. The Council may recess
during the month of August, subject to the call of special meetings or
workshops as prescribed. Seventy- two hours notice at each Council member's
place of residence shall be required before any Council action on any proposed
ordinance or resolution is taken.
(Ord. 98-11-3. Passed 12-1-98; Ord. 2017-2-5. Passed 2-7-17; Ord. 2023-3-4.
Passed 6-6-23.)
   (b)   Special Meetings. Special meetings may be called by a vote of Council
taken at a regular or special meeting thereof, or shall be called by the Clerk-
Treasurer upon request from the Mayor or any three members of Council. Any such
request shall state the time, place, date, and subject matter to be considered
at the meeting. Notice of each such meeting shall be given to each member of
Council by delivery to his or her residence or (by request of the Council
member) to his or her mail slot at the Village Hall not less than twenty-four
hours before a meeting is scheduled. In addition, the Mayor, the Clerk-
Treasurer and the Solicitor shall be similarly served with a notice, but a
failure to send them shall not invalidate an action taken at such meeting. Any
member of Council may expressly waive notice. Residents may request to receive
notification of special meetings through the Village Swift Reach System.
Procedures for establishing notification request forms, as well as Swift Reach
notification shall be administered by the Clerk-Treasurer. Whenever a member of
Council who has not properly been served with a notice is present at such
special meeting, the giving of notice shall be deemed waived by such member.
Legislative action at a special meeting shall be limited to the subject matter
for which the special meeting was called.
   (c)   Workshops. Workshops shall be scheduled as prescribed by Council and
shall be deemed and treated as a special Council meeting with subject matter
that requires an informal atmosphere. Thus, the meeting need not be held in
Council Chambers. The caucus room is sufficient unless there are other
attendees too numerous to accommodate. Notice rules shall be the same as those
for special meeting as set forth in subsection (b) of this section.
(Ord. 96-4-8. Passed 4-2-96; Ord. 2003-2-7. Passed 4-1-03; Ord. 2009-2-8.
Passed 2-3-09; Ord. 2015-3-2. Passed 3-3-15.)
220.02 MEETINGS GENERALLY.
   (a)   Open Meetings. All meetings of Council shall be open to the public,
except as prescribed by Ohio R.C. 121.22.
   (b)   Place of Meetings. All meetings, whether regular or special, shall be
held at the Council Chambers (unless otherwise specified in the meeting notice)
of the Village and shall be open to the public, except as specified by Ohio
R.C. 121.22.
   (c)   Holiday Meetings. When any regular meeting of the Council occurs on a
legal holiday or the day before, or the day after a legal holiday, the Council
may meet in regular session on the Tuesday following such holiday at the place
and hour provided for in subsection (b) hereof and Section
220.01 (a). A legal holiday is a holiday on which Village employees have a
holiday recess.
   (d)   Opening Procedure. The President of Council (the Mayor) shall take the
Chair at the time specified for the Council to meet, shall call the members to
order and shall proceed with the order of business. (See Section
220.08.) In the absence of the President of Council, the President Pro Tempore
of Council shall perform such duties as are imposed upon the presiding officer.
In the absence of the President of Council and the President Pro Tempore, a
Council member who is chosen by a majority of Council members present at the
meeting shall take the Chair.
   (e)   Quorum. A majority of all Council members shall constitute a quorum to
conduct any municipal business.
(Ord. 96-4-8. Passed 4-2-96; Ord. 2003-2-7. Passed 4-1-03; Ord. 2015-3-2.
Passed 3-3-15; Ord. 2016-9-6. Passed 9-13-16.)
220.03 DUTIES OF THE PRESIDING OFFICER; APPEALS FROM DECISIONS OF THE CHAIR.
   (a)   Duties of the Presiding Officer. The presiding officer shall preserve
order and decorum, shall confine members in debate to the question and shall,
when in the Chair, decide all questions of order subject to an appeal to the
Council on demand of two members, at which such time the Solicitor will provide
guidance to any question of order. On such appeal, there shall be no debate,
but the member making the appeal may briefly state his or her reason for the
same, and the presiding officer shall have the same right to make a similar
brief statement.
   (b)   Appeals From Decisions of the Chair. The Chair shall preserve decorum
and decide all questions of order, subject to an appeal to Council. If any
member violates any of the Rules of Council, the Chair shall, or any member
may, call him or her to order and, in the latter instance, the Chair shall
render a decision as to the point of order. In case of an appeal from any
ruling of the Chair, the question shall be: "Shall the decision of the Chair
stand as the decision of Council?" The Chair shall be sustained unless
overruled by a majority vote of the members of Council present.
(Ord. 96-4-8. Passed 4-2-96; Ord. 2015-3-2. Passed 3-3-15.)
220.04 PREPARATION AND DELIVERY OF AGENDA; ADDRESS BY SOLICITOR; CAUCUSES;
REMOVAL OF LEGISLATION.
   (a)   Preparation and Delivery of Agenda. The Mayor shall be responsible for
the preparation of an agenda for each regularly scheduled Council meeting. The
agenda shall follow the order of business set forth in Section
220.08 and shall contain the title of each ordinance and resolution to be
considered by Council and a brief description of new business which the Mayor
anticipates presenting to Council. Persons with business before Council shall
be encouraged to advise the Mayor of the nature of such business in time for
inclusion in the agenda so that Council and the Mayor may prepare for the same.
   (b)   Address by Solicitor. The Solicitor shall be permitted to address
Council at any time on any question or matter then pending or to be considered
by Council, regarding the legal considerations involved therein. This privilege
shall not be subject to amendment, except by a unanimous vote of all members
elected to Council.
   (c)   Caucuses. Joint caucuses with the Administration should start
immediately before a regular meeting of Council. The Clerk-Treasurer (or his or
her representative) shall maintain the normal order of legislation.
   (d)   Removal of Legislation. Any Council member desiring to remove
legislation shall notify the Clerk-Treasurer during (or prior to) the Caucus.
All legislation on first, second and third reading shall be maintained in their
proper order. This will expedite caucus meetings.
(Ord. 96-4-8. Passed 4-2-96; Ord. 2015-3-2. Passed 3-3-15.)
220.05 INTRODUCTION OF LEGISLATION; PREPARATION; DELIVERY.
   (a)   All legislation is to be introduced either by the Mayor or a Council
member or through its proper committee. In order that adequate time may be
given to the preparation of legislation, the person or persons requesting the
legislation shall, in clear terms, present the request for legislation to the
Solicitor, in writing, not later than seven days preceding the meeting for
which action or consideration is sought thereon. The person or persons
requesting the legislation shall have his or her or their names appear on the
legislation as the introducer or introducers thereof. All legislation prepared
shall be given a number and placed on the agenda of the next regular meeting of
Council if it is delivered to Council members at least seven days prior to said
meeting.
   (b)   The Clerk-Treasurer shall deliver, or cause to be delivered, to all
members of Council, such ordinances or resolutions with related materials and
finance materials, as are specified by ordinance. Delivery shall be made by the
Police Department to the member's residence or in Council mail slots in the
Village Hall (if requested by Council members).
   (c)   All request/ordinances regarding the hiring of, promoting of, or
changing position of any position in the Police Department or the Fire
Department shall be submitted to the appropriate committee chairman at the
Village Hall or by mail or personal delivery at least fifteen days before a
regular Council meeting for committee review and evaluation and shall be placed
on first reading unless an emergency exists as determined by Council.
“Appropriate committee” means the committee most closely related to the
position.
(Ord. 96-5-9. Passed 6-4-96; Ord. 2000-2-5. Passed 4-4-00; Ord. 2010-12-9.
Passed 1-4-11; Ord. 2015-3-2. Passed 3-3-15.)
220.06 PRESIDENT PRO TEMPORE; ABSENCE OF CLERK-TREASURER; VACANCIES.
   (a)   President Pro Tempore. At the regular meeting in January of each year,
Council shall immediately proceed to elect a President Pro Tempore from its own
number, who shall serve until the first meeting in January next after his or
her election as President Pro Tempore. If the President Pro Tempore should
succeed to the office of Mayor, then Council shall fill the vacancy thus
created (President Pro Tempore), in accordance with subsection (c) hereof, and
thereafter elect another President Pro Tempore from its own number, who shall
have the same rights, powers and duties as his or her predecessor.
   (b)   Absence of Clerk-Treasurer. In case of the absence of the Clerk-
Treasurer from any Council meeting, Council shall appoint one of its own
members to perform the duties of the Clerk-Treasurer at such meeting. Meeting
minutes shall be the responsibility of the Clerk-Treasurer and shall be
delivered to the Council members and Village Hall mail boxes within seven days
after the meeting for which they were written.
   (c)   Vacancies. When the office of a member of Council becomes vacant, the
vacancy shall be filled by election by a majority vote of all members elected
to Council for the unexpired term, provided, however, that if Council fails to
fill such vacancy within thirty days, the Mayor shall fill it by appointment.
   (d)   Additional compensation. Effective January 1, 2002, a member of
Council serving as President of Council Pro Tempore shall receive additional
compensation of one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00) per year, payable
bi-weekly.
(Ord. 96-4-8. Passed 4-2-96; Ord. 2002-2-5. Passed 2-5-02; Ord. 2015-3-2.
Passed 3-3-15.)
220.07 MOTIONS.
   (a)   In General. When a motion is made and seconded, it shall be stated by
the Chair before debate and recorded by the Clerk-Treasurer. A motion shall
pass upon receiving the affirmative vote of the majority of the members
present.
   (b)   Robert's Rules of Order. Robert's Rules of Order (the most recent
edition) shall govern the deliberations of Council.
   (c)   Suspension of Rules. These rules, or any of them, may be temporarily
suspended at any meeting of the Council by a concurrent vote of the majority of
all members elected, except when a greater number is required by law or by
these rules. The vote on such suspension shall be taken and entered in the
Journal. In case any rule herein shall not have been adhered to by the Council,
the same shall be regarded as having been suspended.
   (d)   Public Hearings. With the approval of a majority of Council, a
committee may hold a public hearing in connection with any matter under
consideration before it.
(Ord. 96-4-8. Passed 4-2-96; Ord. 2015-3-2. Passed 3-3-15.)
220.08 ORDER OF BUSINESS.
   The order of business at meetings of Council shall be:
   (a)   Call to order.
   (b)   Pledge of Allegiance.
   (c)   Mayor’s report.
   (d)   Reading and approval of the minutes; corrections, if any.
   (e)   Introduction and consideration of new ordinances and resolutions.
   (f)   Reports of special committees and discussion.
   (g)   Reports of Municipal officers and discussion.
   (h)   New business from Council.
   (i)   Open to the audience for questions and comments.
   (j)   Adjournment.
   The order of business shall be subject to change by a majority vote of the
members of Council.
(Ord. 96-4-8. Passed 4-2-96; Ord. 2015-3-2. Passed 3-3-15.)
220.09 DISTURBING COUNCIL.
   No person shall purposely disturb a Council meeting or workshop by
disorderly conduct or obscene language, or interfere with a Council meeting
while addressing Council by using obscene language toward any person or member
of Council.
(Ord. 96-4-8. Passed 4-2-96; Ord. 2015-3-2. Passed 3-3-15.)
220.10 COMMITTEES.
   (a)   Standing Committees Established. The following standing committees of
Council are hereby established:
      (1)   Safety (Police and Fire)
      (2)   Finance
      (3)   Road, Traffic, Utility and Engineering
      (4)   Recreation
      (5)   Legislative
      (6)   Building and Building Maintenance (Building Inspector)
      (7)   Landscape & Beautification.
(Ord. 2002-2-4. Passed 2-5-02; Ord. 2011-1-4. Passed 1-4-11; Ord. 2023-1-8.
Passed 1-10-23.)
   (b)   Appointments to Standing Committees. On or before the February Council
meeting each year the President Pro Tem shall appoint members of Council to
standing committees and appoint the Chairpersons thereof. The President Pro
Tempore, in making such appointments, shall be guided by the qualifications of
the members of Council. Each Councilperson will be appointed to serve as the
chairperson of not less than one committee. Each Councilperson will be placed
on at least one committee from a list of his or her top three choices of
committees, as submitted in writing to the President Pro Tempore by the twenty-
first of January. Each standing committee shall consist of not less than two
nor more than four members, except that the Finance Committee shall consist of
three members of Council. No member of Council shall serve on more than four
standing committees.
(Ord. 2023-3-5. Passed 5-2-23.)
   (c)   Special Committees. The President Pro Tempore shall appoint such
special committees as the Mayor or a majority of the members of Council deems
necessary, provided, however, that any matter properly the concern of any
standing committee, or which is then referred to or pending before such
standing committee, may not, without the consent of such standing committee, be
referred to or considered by a special committee.
(Ord. 96-12-14. Passed 12-20-96.)
   (d)   Representative To Cuyahoga Heights Schools and Board of Education. The
President Pro Tempore shall appoint one Councilmember to be a representative
and liaison to Cuyahoga Heights High School. This shall not prevent other
Council members from having communications with the schools, but shall serve as
a main course of communication to the school administration and Board of
Education.
(Ord. 97-12-5. Passed 12-2-97.)
   (e)   Committee of the Whole. Council may resolve itself into a Committee of
the Whole.
   (f)   Committee Secretary. Each committee may elect a secretary from among
its members to keep a record of attendance and business transacted.
   (g)   Chairpersons of Committees.
      (1)   The President Pro Tempore shall appoint the chairpersons of the
special committees.
      (2)   In the absence of a committee chairperson, the other members
present, if constituting a quorum, shall elect a temporary chairperson.
(Ord. 96-12-14. Passed 12-20-96.)
   (h)   Meetings; Notice. The Finance Committee shall meet at 6:30 p.m. or
another time as determined by the Chairperson, at the Village Hall, on regular
Council meeting nights. Otherwise, each committee shall meet on the call of its
Chairperson, or at the request of a majority of the members thereof, upon at
least 24 hours written notice of the date and time of such meeting to each
committee member, and to the President Pro Tempore, such notice to be served
personally or left at the person's usual place of residence. Each member may
waive such notice. The presence of any member at any committee meeting shall be
deemed a waiver by such member of any irregularity in notice. By a unanimous
vote of all members appointed to a committee, such committee shall have the
power to vary the notice requirements of this subsection, except that in no
event shall any such variance eliminate the requirement of notifying the
President Pro Tempore of any meeting.
(Ord. 98-11-2. Passed 12-1-98.)
   (i)   Reports. Committee reports shall be in writing, except when waived by
Council. The report of a majority of the members of a committee shall
constitute the report of the committee, provided, however, that any member is
entitled to prepare and present to Council a minority report. Council may
accept or reject any committee report, in whole or in part.
   Upon motion and by a majority vote, Council may relieve a committee of
further consideration of any question before it and order such matter placed on
the calendar. When any matter is referred to a committee with instructions to
report at a time named in the order or reference, failure to report at such
time shall be considered as if reported back without recommendation, unless the
time for such report is extended by Council. If no such extension is granted,
the committee shall forthwith return to the Clerk the documents pertaining to
such matter, and such matter shall take its appropriate place on the calendar.
   (j)   Public Hearings. With the approval of a majority of Council, a
committee may hold a public hearing in connection with any matter under
consideration before it.
(Ord. 96-12-14. Passed 12-20-96; Ord. 2015-3-2. Passed 3-3-15.)
220.11 ADDITIONAL COMPENSATION.
   (a)   Effective January 1, 2002, a member of Council serving on the Finance
Committee shall receive additional compensation of nine hundred dollars
($900.00) per year, payable bi-weekly. Said nine hundred dollars ($900.00)
shall be in addition to the Councilperson’s regular salary.
   (b)   Effective January 1, 2002, all parties serving on the following
standing committees of council shall receive additional compensation of five
hundred dollars ($500.00) per year in one lump sum. Said five hundred dollars
($500.00) shall be in addition to the Councilpersons regular salary.
      (1)   Building & Building Maintenance;
      (2)   Road, Traffic, Utility and Engineering;
      (3)   Insurance; Human Services, Office Services;
      (4)   Landscape & Beautification;
      (5)   Safety;
      (6)   Recreation.
   (c)   Effective January 1, 2012, all members of Council shall receive a six
hundred dollar ($600.00) (per member) allowance to attend seminars, purchase
publications, and provide for associated incidental supplies.
(Ord. 2002-4-7. Passed 4-16-02; Ord. 2011-1-5. Passed 1-4-11; Ord. 2012-1-3.
Passed 1-3-12; Ord. 2015-3-2. Passed 3-3-15.)
220.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates Section
220.09 is guilty of a minor misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than one
hundred fifty dollars ($150.00).
(Ord. 96-4-8. Passed 4-2-96; Ord. 2015-3-2. Passed 3-3-15.)

222.01 POSTING PLACES.
   (a)   All ordinances, resolutions, statements, orders, proclamations,
notices and reports required by law or ordinance to be published shall be
published by posting copies thereof, for a period of not less than fifteen days
prior to the taking effect thereof, in the five most public places in the
Village, which are determined to be as follows:
      (1)   The Village Hall, 6848 Hathaway Road;
      (2)   The Valley View Community Center, 6828 Hathaway Road;
      (3)   Corner of Tinkers Creek Road and Canal Road;
      (4)   Don Miller Park/Tiny Lane, Fosdick and Murray Roads; and
      (5)   Corner of Stone Road and Canal Road.
   (b)   The Clerk shall make a certificate as to such posting and as to the
time when and the places where such posting is done, in the manner provided in
Ohio R.C. 731.25, and such certificate shall be prima-facie evidence that the
copies were posted as required.
   (c)   Notices to bidders for the construction of public improvements and
notices of the sale of bonds shall be published in not more than two
newspapers, printed in Ohio and of general circulation in the Village, for the
time prescribed in Ohio R.C. 731.22.
(ORC 731.25; Ord. 86-7-3. Passed 7-1-86; Ord. 2010-12-10. Passed 12-7-10.)

230.02 OFFICE HOURS.
   Commencing January 1, 1984, the Mayor should be immediately available
between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 4:30 p.m., Monday through Friday, to perform
the duties of the Mayor as prescribed by law and such other duties that have
become necessary to preserve and protect the health, welfare and safety of the
residents of the Village.
(Ord. 83-2-8. Passed 2-1-83.)
230.03 EXECUTIVE ASSISTANT TO THE MAYOR.
   (a)   Appointment and duties. There is hereby created the position of
Executive Assistant ot the Mayor who shall be appointed by and serve at the
pleasure of the Mayor. The Executive Assistant’s primary responsibility shall
be to maintain quality assurance within the village’s government by
coordinating and organizing all communication between the Mayor’s
administration, the village’s residents and other elected officials. This
individual shall advise and consult with directors, departments, divisions,
boards and commissions regarding public relations aspects and will serve as a
resource person for information on positive public presentation of village
programs and activities. The Executive Assistant shall coordinate complaint
resolution with members of Council.
   (b)   Maximum hours. The Executive Assistant to the Mayor may work a maximum
of 28 hours per week.
   (c)   Salary. The salary for the Executive Assistant to the Mayor shall be
set at twenty dollars and fifty cents ($20.50) and is not eligible for any
other benefits and shall remain in force until changed by Council.
(Ord. 88-3-19. Passed 3-1-88; Ord. 2008-1-4. Passed 1-14-08.)
230.04AUTHORITY TO ACCEPT CASH AND PROPERTY.
   (a)   Mandatory Drug Fines.
      (1)   The Mayor is hereby authorized and directed to accept cash from the
mandatory drug fines imposed on convicted drug offenders in accordance with the
provisions of Ohio R.C. 2925.03(J) and (K) and
Chapter 622 of these Codified Ordinances.
      (2)   The Mayor is hereby directed to place all cash received into a
special law enforcement mandatory drug fine fund with the Clerk-Treasurer to be
used solely for the Police Department's law enforcement efforts pertaining to
drug offenses. Said fund shall be separate and apart from other special funds
established.
(Ord. 91-12-4. Passed 12-3-91.)
   (b)   Drug Penalty Act of 1984.
      (1)   The Mayor is hereby authorized and directed to accept cash and
other tangible personal property from the United States Government in
accordance with the comprehensive Drug Penalty Act of 1984. However, any
acceptance of real estate by the Mayor shall be subject to approval by
ordinance of Council.
      (2)   The Mayor is hereby directed to place all cash received into a
special fund with the Clerk-Treasurer to be used solely for law enforcement
purposes.
      (3)   All tangible personal property shall be brass tagged or become an
asset to the Police Department to be used solely for law enforcement purposes.
(Ord. 91-12-5. Passed 12-3-91.)
   (c)   Contraband Seizure Forfeiture Act.
      (1)   The Mayor is hereby authorized and directed to accept cash,
vehicles and other property in accordance with the Contraband Seizure
Forfeiture Act, Ohio R.C. 2933.43. However, any acceptance of real estate by
the Mayor shall be subject to approval by ordinance of Council.
      (2)   The Mayor is hereby authorized and directed to accept all cash
received into a special law enforcement trust fund with the Clerk-Treasurer to
be used solely for law enforcement purposes. Said fund shall be separate and
apart from other special funds established.
      (3)   All vehicles and property shall be assetted or brass tagged to the
Police Department to be used solely for law enforcement purposes, or sold and
the proceeds from the sale deposited in the special law enforcement trust fund,
as directed by the Chief of Police.
(Ord. 91-12-6. Passed 12-3-91.)

232.001 MERGER OF OFFICES OF CLERK AND TREASURER.
   Commencing with the general election to be held on November 5, 1991, the
offices of Clerk and Treasurer will be combined into one office to be known as
the Clerk-Treasurer, which person shall be elected for a term of four years
commencing on April 1 next year after his or her election. Said Clerk-Treasurer
shall be an elector of the Village of Valley View.
(Ord. 91-5-4. Passed 6-4-91.)
232.01 DISTRIBUTION OF COPIES OF MINUTES.
   (a)   The Clerk-Treasurer shall, not later than the twelfth day of each
month, proceed to distribute copies of the minutes of all regular Council
meetings that have been approved by Council during the preceding month, to all
residents in the Village who desire such copies. Residents must submit a
request to the Clerk-Treasurer's office to be included in the mailing of such
minutes.
(Ord. 99-12-11. Passed 1-4-2000.)
   (b)   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Subsection (b) was repealed by Ordinance 99-12-11,
passed January 4, 2000).
   (c)   Council hereby authorizes the Clerk-Treasurer to expend such
additional funds as are necessary to reproduce and distribute the minutes.
   (d)   The Clerk-Treasurer shall specifically and clearly identify on all pay
ordinances submitted to Council those additional funds that have been expended
for the reproduction and distribution of the minutes.
(Ord. 77-5-6. Passed 5-3-77; Ord. 91-5-4. Passed 6-4-91.)
232.02 SENIOR CLERK-TREASURER; ADDITIONAL EMPLOYEES.
   (a)   There is hereby established the full-time position of Senior Clerk-
Treasurer to per form duties set forth by the elected Clerk-Treasurer.
   (b)   The compensation for such full-time position shall be determined from
time to time by Council, in addition to all benefits payable to other full-time
employees, with the exception of longevity compensation and clothing allowance.
(Ord. 88-3-14. Passed 3-1-88; Ord. 91-5-4. Passed 6-4-91.)
   (c)   The Clerk-Treasurer shall hire the Senior Clerk-Treasurer and any
other employee required by the Clerk-Treasurer, and which positions are
authorized by Council.
(Ord. 98-3-11. Passed 3-3-98.)
232.03 INVESTMENT OF SURPLUS FUNDS.
   (a)   Whenever there are moneys in the Treasury of the Village which will
not be required to be used by the Village for a period of six months or more,
such moneys may, in lieu of being deposited in a bank or banks, be invested in
obligations of the Village or in such other bonds or obligations as are or may
be specified in Ohio R.C. 731.56.
   (b)   Such investments shall be made pursuant to the provisions of Ohio R.C.
731.56 to 731.59, inclusive.
(Ord. 69-10-4. Passed 10-7-69.)
232.04 REWARD FUND FOR INFORMATION RE VANDALISM OF MUNICIPAL PROPERTY.
   (a)   There is hereby established a reward fund in the amount of one
thousand dollars ($1,000).
   (b)   A sum of up to one thousand dollars ($1,000) may be paid to any person
or persons who furnish information leading to the arrest and conviction of
persons causing vandalism or damage to Village property. Said property shall
include buildings and land of any kind titled to the Village. The amount of the
reward, which shall not exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000), shall be
determined by the majority of Council based on the damage and/or severity to
the Village property.
(Ord. 90-8-2. Passed 8-1-90.)

238.01 COMPOSITION.
   (a)   The Police Department shall be composed of a Chief of Police, one
Lieutenant, four Sergeants, at least one full-time Detective, and not less than
eight full-time patrolmen, all appointed by the Mayor and confirmed by Council.
   (b)   The positions of Lieutenant, and Sergeants will all be filled from the
full-time ranks of the Valley View Police Department pursuant to
Chapter 245, Police Department Testing and Promotion.
(Ord. 98-4-3. Passed 4-7-98; Ord. 2000-5-10. Passed 6-6-00; Ord. 2005-4-7.
Passed 4-5-05; Ord. 2011-2-2. Passed 2-1-11; Ord. 2013-1-8. Passed 2-5-13.)
   (c)   The position of full-time Detective shall be appointed from the full-
time ranks of the Valley View Police Department by the Mayor with the
recommendation of the Chief of Police. Full-time Detectives completing five
years of continuous service shall be appointed to the rank of Detective First
Grade, equal in authority and compensation to the rank of Sergeant. Should a
Detective First Grade resign or leave the position for any reason, he or she
would return to the rank of patrolman.
   (d)   There shall also be four part-time policemen who shall be appointed by
the Mayor and confirmed by Council from time to time.
(Ord. 92-10-10. Passed 10-20-92; Ord. 2004-6-7. Passed 6-17-04; Ord. 2018-10-6.
Passed 11-6-18.)
238.02 CHARGES FOR REPORTS.
   (a)   The fee for each page of any police report or other public record
shall be twenty-five cents ($.25) per page.
(Ord. 83-5-5. Passed 5-3-83; Ord. 2000-6-6. Passed 6-6-00.)
   (b)   The fees provided to be charged herein shall be set by the Chief of
Police and may be collected by him, or anyone designated by him to receive such
moneys, and shall be paid over to the Village Treasurer monthly, into the
General Fund.
(Ord. 63-11-5. Passed 11-5-63.)
238.03 APPOINTMENT OF JANITOR-JAILOR.
   (a)   The Mayor shall, whenever the occasion requires it, appoint a suitable
person to the position of Janitor-Jailor, by and with the consent of Council,
and pay compensation therefor as approved by Council.
(1965 Code Sec. 141.09)
   (b)   ( Editor's note: Subsection (b) hereof was repealed by Ordinance 90-
12-17, passed December 4, 1990.)
238.035 APPOINTMENT AND COMPENSATION OF ASSISTANT JAILORS.
   (a)   The Mayor is hereby authorized to compile a list of persons designed
to work as Assistant Jailors and to be hired on a part-time basis.
(Ord. 91-12-17. Passed 12-10-91.)
   (b)   Said Assistant Jailors shall not be permitted to be employed for more
than forty hours per week and shall be paid at a rate determined by Council
from time to time.
(Ord. 96-7-21. Passed 7-24-96.)
   (c)   A successful applicant for the position of Assistant Jailor shall have
attained the minimum age of eighteen years.
   (d)   The initial list shall consist of twenty persons who shall receive
work assignments as set forth by the Mayor and/or Chief Jailor.
(Ord. 91-12-17. Passed 12-10-91.)
   (e)   Assistant Jailors shall be paid time and one-half for hours worked on
the following holidays: New Year's Day, Easter Sunday, Memorial Day,
Independence Day, Thanksgiving Day and Christmas Day.
   (f)   Part-time Assistant Jailors will be paid a minimum of two hours
"report for duty pay." However, if said employees are notified eight hours in
advance, there will be no report for duty pay paid.
(Ord. 96-7-21. Passed 7-24-96.)
238.04 PART-TIME PATROLMEN AND SPECIAL POLICEMEN; COMPENSATION AND BOND.
(REPEALED)
238.05 APPOINTMENT OF DOG WARDEN.
   The Mayor shall, whenever the occasion requires it, appoint a suitable
person to the position of Dog Warden, by and with the consent of Council, and
pay compensation therefor, as approved by Council. The Dog Warden shall enforce
Chapter 955 of the Ohio Revised Code,
Chapter 618 of these Codified Ordinances and any other laws of the State and
the Village related thereto.
(Ord. 67-7-4. Passed 7-11-67.)
238.06 MATRON OF JAILS AND COORDINATOR.
   (a)   There is hereby created the position of Matron of Jails and
Coordinator of other Village activities at a salary to be determined by Council
from time to time.
   (b)   Said position will include paid holidays and paid vacation.
   (c)   Said person appointed shall not be entitled to hospitalization or any
other benefits.
   (d)   Said person shall be appointed to said position by the Mayor, with the
approval of Council.
(Ord. 90-2-19. Passed 2-6-90.)
238.07 POLICE PROTECTION OUTSIDE MUNICIPALITY.
   (a)   Council hereby authorizes the police department to provide police
protection to any county, municipal corporation or township of this State upon
authorization of the officer or employee of the department designated in
subsection (b) hereof.
   (b)   The Chief of Police, or his or her designee, is hereby designated as
the officer or employee of the department to give such authorization as may be
appropriate pursuant to subsection (a) hereof.
(Res. 89-6-9. Passed 6-6-89.)
238.08 POLICE CONFIDENTIAL INVESTIGATION FUND.
   (a)   Creation. There is hereby created a fund which shall be designated as
the Police Confidential Investigation Fund, which shall be in the amount of one
thousand, five hundred dollars ($1,500), and which shall be for the use of the
Police Department, to be appropriated in and included as part of the annual
appropriation for the General Fund to the Police Department. The Police Chief,
with the approval of the Mayor, may pay rewards up to five hundred dollars
($500.00) each from the Fund to persons furnishing information which leads to
the arrest and conviction of persons omitting any misdemeanor set forth in the
General Offenses Code of these Codified Ordinances or violating any statute set
forth in Ohio R.C. Chapter 3719.
   (b)   Custody and Jurisdiction. The Chief of the Police Department, and any
person or persons authorized by him in writing, shall have sole custody of and
jurisdiction over the Police Confidential Investigation Fund, which Fund shall
be used by the Police Department for confidential investigation to determine
whether the criminal laws of the Village, State or Federal Government have been
violated. No part of this Fund shall be paid directly or indirectly to any
person or persons employed by the Village.
   (c)   Accounting for Expenditures. The Chief of the Police Department shall,
when necessary to restore the amount of the Police Confidential Investigation
Fund, account for expenditures from the Fund by delivery to the Clerk-Treasurer
of appropriate vouchers and receipts, evidencing each and every expenditure
from such Fund, and he or she shall, annually, at the close of the fiscal year,
provide a written report to the Clerk-Treasurer, showing a complete and
adequate reporting of the receipts and expenditures of the Fund, together with
a description of the purpose of the expenditure. The Clerk-Treasurer is hereby
authorized and directed to reimburse the Fund upon receipt of properly executed
vouchers and receipts for investigation items, the cost of which cannot be
recovered or reimbursed.
(Ord. 92-3-13. Passed 3-11-92.)
238.09 COMPENSATION FOR POLICE TRAINING.
   (a)   Any full-time police officer who leaves the Police Department or is
terminated for any reason within five years of employment shall recompense the
Village for all monies expended for training received and any tuition costs.
   (b)   The Police Chief is hereby directed to have all police personnel
execute an agreement as set forth in Exhibit A, attached to Ordinance No. 2002-
6-2, passed July 2, 2002, and incorporated herein as if fully rewritten.
(Ord. 2002-6-2. Passed 7-2-02.)

240.01 ESTABLISHMENT; COMPOSITION.
   There is hereby established a Fire Department, which shall be composed of a
full-time Fire Chief, and who shall act as the Administrator of the Fire
Department, not less than eleven full-time firefighters, three of whom shall be
Lieutenants, and up to twenty-five part-time firefighters, with basic training
(minimum) as the Mayor, the Fire Chief and Council deem necessary.
(Ord. 99-7-3. Passed 7-6-99; Ord. 2000-9-13. Passed 9-5-00; Ord. 2005-5-2.
Passed 5-3-05; Ord. 2008-4-3. Passed 6-3-08; Ord. 2016-4-4. Passed 4-5-16.)
240.02 APPOINTMENTS; PARAMEDIC TRAINING.
   (a)   The Chief of the Fire Department shall be appointed by the Mayor, with
the advice and consent of a majority of Council, and shall continue in office
until removed therefrom in the manner provided by law.
   (b)   All full-time personnel of the Department shall be appointed by the
Mayor with the advice and consent of Council and the recommendation of the Fire
Chief.
   (c)   Part-time firefights shall be appointed by the Mayor with the advice
and consent of a majority of Council, as provided by law.
   (d)   No person shall be finally appointed until he or she has received the
certificate required by Ohio R.C. 737.22 and has passed the physical
examination required by such statute.
   (e)   An appointment made under this section shall be for a probationary
period of one year after successful certification as an Emergency Medical
Technician - Ambulance (EMT-A) and after successful certification as a
Firefighter 1.
   (f)   All full-time firefighters, after they have completed their initial
training under subsection (e) hereof, shall attend the first available
paramedic program, as determined by the Fire Chief.
   (g)   All firefighter/paramedics shall successfully complete a paramedic
course and obtain a paramedic certification from the state within one year
after the completion of their probationary period, and shall thereafter at all
times maintain a current paramedic certification, including any continuing
education. Failure to secure paramedic certification within one year after
completion of the probationary period or to maintain current paramedic
certification throughout the individual’s period of employment, regardless of
rank (except the Chief), shall be considered an act of nonfeasance in office
and grounds for disciplinary action.
   (h)   All part-time employees shall maintain their current certification
(EMT, paramedic, Firefighter 1 and 2 certificates) throughout the individual's
period of employment. In the event a part-time employee would change his or her
certification level anytime during his or her employment, this change would be
considered an act of nonfeasance in office and grounds for disciplinary action
up to and including termination.
(Ord. 90-5-4. Passed 5-1-90; Ord. 2008-4-4. Passed 6-4-08; Ord. 2010-11-5.
Passed 12-7-10.)
240.03 DUTIES.
   (a)   The Chief of the Fire Department shall perform all of the duties
usually and customarily performed by persons holding such rank with the State
and such duties as may be prescribed by ordinance.
   (b)   The duties of personnel in the Department, except for the Fire Chief,
shall include, but shall not be limited to, the fighting of fires, the
performing of rescue work, the providing of emergency ambulance services, the
performance of assignments relating to flood control, fire inspections and fire
prevention, the maintenance of hydrants, the maintenance of equipment, the
performance of housekeeping chores relating to the fire station, the keeping of
records, the providing of instruction to other members of the Department and to
residents of the village and such other duties as may be prescribed by
ordinance.
   (c)   The Chief shall determine from time to time the duties and
responsibilities of each officer of the Department.
(Ord. 78-2-3. Passed 2-7-78; Ord. 2008-4-5. Passed 6-3-08.)
240.04 RECORDS.
   The Fire Chief shall keep in convenient form a complete record of all fires.
Such record shall include the time of the alarm; the location of the fire, the
cause of the fire, if known; the type of building; the name of the owner and
tenant; the purpose for which it is occupied, the value of the building and its
contents, the members of the Fire Department responding to the alarm; and such
other information as he deems advisable or as may be required from time to time
by Council.
(Ord. 78-2-3. Passed 2-7-78; Ord. 2008-4-7. Passed 6-3-08.)
240.05 PRACTICE DRILLS.
   (a)   The Fire Chief shall hold, as needed, practice drills of at least one
hour for full-time and part-time firefighters. At such practice drills, the
Fire Chief, or his or her designee, shall give the firefighters instructions in
approved methods of fire fighting and fire prevention.
(Ord. 99-10-18. Passed 12-7-99.)
   (b)   For attending fire drills as requested by the Fire Chief, members of
the Fire Department shall be compensated at their regular rate of pay nearest
to the quarter hour, payable bi-weekly upon certification by the Fire Chief.
(Ord. 86-3-16. Passed 3-4-86.)
   (c)   Full-time members of the Fire Department shall be allowed to drill
with part-time firefighters, as deemed necessary by the Fire Chief.
(Ord. 99-10-18. Passed 12-7-99.)
240.06 DISPOSITION OF COMBUSTIBLE WASTE MATERIAL.
   The Fire Chief shall be responsible for the supervision of the collection,
removal and disposition of combustible waste material within the Village.
(Ord. 78-2-3. Passed 2-7-78.)
240.07 LOSS OF MEMBERSHIP.
   Firefighters absent from twenty percent of all drills offered per calendar
year without being excused by the Fire Chief or Assistant Fire Chief shall be
subject to reprimand, suspension or dismissal from the Fire Department.
(Ord. 89-1-23. Passed 1-3-89.)
240.08 VACATIONS AND HOLIDAYS.
   (a)   Every full-time member of the Fire Department, except the Fire Chief,
who works the regular twenty-four to forty-eight hour work schedule, shall be
entitled to the following vacation allowance:
   Years of Continuous Service   Tours of Duty
   After one         Five
   After five         Seven
   After ten         Nine
   After fifteen         Eleven
   After twenty         Twelve
   (b)   Every full-time member of the Fire Department, with the exception of
the Fire Chief, shall be entitled to six tours of duty off instead of receiving
the nine paid holidays and three personal days.
   (c)   The Chief of the Fire Department will be entitled to ten working days
vacation during the calendar year after his first year of continuous service,
eleven working days vacation after completing five years of service, twelve
working days vacation after completing six years of service, thirteen working
days vacation after completing seven years of service, fourteen working days
vacation after completing eight years of service, fifteen working days vacation
after completing nine years of service, sixteen working days vacation after
completing ten years of service, seventeen working days vacation after
completing eleven years of service, eighteen working days vacation after
completing twelve years of service, nineteen working days vacation after
completing thirteen years of service, twenty working days vacation after
completing fourteen years of service, twenty-one working days vacation after
completing fifteen years of service, twenty-two working days vacation after
completing sixteen years of service, twenty-three working days vacation after
completing seventeen years of service, twenty-four working days vacation after
completing eighteen years of service, twenty-five working days vacation after
completing nineteen years of service and twenty-five working days vacation
after completing twenty years of service.
(Ord. 94-6-6. Passed 6-21-94.)
   (d)   The Chief of the Fire Department shall be entitled to the following
nine paid holidays: New Year's Day, Good Friday, Memorial Day, Independence
Day, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day and Christmas Day, two unnamed holidays, and
three personal days, one of which will be the employee's birthday, all of which
must be taken as time off, and within the calendar year.
(Ord. 99-10-19. Passed 12-7-99.)

240.10 COMPENSATION AND OVERTIME.

to time by Council.
(Adopting Ordinance)
   (b)   Overtime for all full-time firefighters, with the exception of the
Fire Chief, shall be paid at the rate of an additional fifty percent of the
employee's regular hourly rate of pay for any hours worked beyond 159 hours in
any twenty-one day work period. Full-time firefighters shall work an average of
fifty-six hours per week. Overtime compensation earned will be paid no later
than the second succeeding pay period from which it is earned.
(Ord. 94-6-8. Passed 6-7-94.)
240.11 HOSPITALIZATION.
   The Fire Chief and each full-time member of the Fire Department shall
receive hospitalization insurance coverage.

240.13 ATTENDANCE AT SCHOOLS.
   For attending EMT-A School and for attending the basic course in
Firefighting School, each member of the Fire Department shall receive one
hundred fifty dollars ($150.00), plus mileage, for attending 110 hours of
training sessions which are done in two separate classes. For attending school
for the purpose of updating the EMT-A certificate and the basic course in
firefighting certificate, as required by the laws of the State, each member of
the Department shall be compensated at the current minimum wage, plus mileage,
payable at the completion of the required schooling, upon certification by the
Fire Chief.
(Ord. 97-10-12. Passed 11-4-97.)
240.14 INCENTIVE BONUS FOR PARAMEDIC CERTIFICATES.
   (a)   Upon receipt of a paramedic certificate, each firefighter shall
receive an incentive bonus of one thousand dollars ($1,000).
(Ord. 96-7-22. Passed 7-24-96.)
   (b)   A part-time employee qualified as a paramedic and working a minimum of
400 hours in that year shall receive nine hundred dollars ($900) per year to be
paid in two separate payments of four hundred fifty dollars ($450) each. After
200 hours are worked on or before June 30, the first payment ($450) will be
paid during the first pay period in July. After 200 hours are worked between
July 1 and December 31, the second payment ($450) will be paid in the first pay
period following December 31. The paramedic must work 200 hours during each of
the two pay periods to be eligible for the incentive bonus. Hours worked other
than scheduled duty hours (drill, ext. drills, CPA classes, sick time, etc.) do
not count towards the 400 hours required.
(Ord. 99-11-2. Passed 12-7-99; Ord. 2004-10-4. Passed 12-7-04; Ord. 2008-4-6.
Passed 6-3-08.)
240.15 FEES FOR FIRE REPORTS.
   Fees for fire reports shall be as follows:
   (a)   Ten cents (.10) for each page of the report.
   (b)   Two dollars and fifty cents ($2.50) for each additional page.
(Ord. 85-3-21. Passed 3-5-85; Ord. 2008-4-8. Passed 4-1-08.)
240.16 SNOW PLOWING SERVICES FOR ELDERLY OR DISABLED RESIDENTS. (REPEALED).

passed March 25, 2009. For current provisions regarding snow plowing services

240.17 COMPENSATION FOR TEACHING.
   Members of the Fire Department shall be compensated at their regular rate of
pay, nearest to the quarter hour, for teaching classes which are mandated by
the State to certain Village employees, payable bi-weekly upon certification by
the Fire Chief.
(Ord. 86-3-16. Passed 3-4-86.)
240.18 COMPENSATION FOR HOLIDAYS.
   Effective January 1, 2000, part-time firefighters shall have seven holidays
paid at time and one-half. Such holiday pay will be paid for the hours worked
on the day of the holiday, between the hours of 6:00 a.m. on the day of the
holiday to 6:00 a.m. of the following day, for the following holidays:
      New Year's Day
      Easter
      Memorial Day
      Independence Day
      Labor Day
      Thanksgiving
      Christmas Day
(Ord. 99-11-3. Passed 12-7-99.)
240.19 MINIMUM STANDARDS FOR APPOINTMENT.
   (a)   Part-time and full-time firefighters must, as a minimum, be able to
complete the following agility tests in the times allotted:
      (1)   Task 1 - stair climb with high-rise pack.
         A.   The applicant will carry a high-rise standpipe pack (2-50 foot
sections of 1½ inch hose weighing 50 pounds) to the third floor of the fire
tower.
         B.   The applicant will deposit the hose in the designated location.
         C.   After task number two is completed, this hose will then be
returned down the stairs to the starting location.
         The maximum amount of time for completion of this task is four minutes
and 30 seconds.
      (2)   Task 2 - hose hoist. The applicant, from a third story window,
using a hand motion, hoists a 50 foot donut roll of 2½ inch hose (about 50
pounds) connected by 5/8 inch rope. This task will be completed twice.
   The maximum amount of time for completion of this task is four minutes and
30 seconds.
      (3)   Task 3 - forcible entry. The applicant using the Kaiser Force
Machine and a nine pound hammer, will drive a steel beam five feet.
      (4)   Task 4 - hose advance. The applicant will pick up the nozzle and
move a 1.5 inch charged hose straight forward 75 feet.
      (5)   Task 5 - victim rescue. The applicant will drag a 165 pound dummy a
distance of 100 feet.
   (b)   The time recommended by the Northeast Ohio Fire Chief's Association
for completion of these tests is four minutes and 30 seconds. Cuyahoga
Community College will issue a certificate indicating the time it takes to
complete the tasks. The class participants will be responsible for taking their
certificate of completion to the jurisdiction for which they are applying.
   (c)   The certificates will be valid for one year. Applicants must be sure
that the fire departments where they are applying for a position will accept
the certificate as their standard.
   (d)   Part-time firefighters who have passed all the minimum standards and
who are applying for status as full-time firefighters must be re-tested and
complete all of the standards set forth in this section.
   (e)   All part-time and full-time firefighters who have been on a leave of
absence for more than one year must be re-tested and complete all of the
standards set forth in this section.
(Ord. 93-1-15. Passed 3-2-93; Ord. 2004-5-2. Passed 5-4-04.)
240.20 LEAVES OF ABSENCE.
   A leave of absence for one year from the Fire Department may be granted by
the Fire Chief. Upon return to active service, the Fire Chief and the
departmental officer shall determine if the firefighter is mentally and
physically fit to resume the duties of a firefighter. During the leave of
absence, the firefighter shall continue with the educational requirements and
certification at his or her expense. This requirement is necessary for
reinstatement. A physical examination shall also be required for reinstatement.
(Ord. 89-1-24. Passed 1-3-89.)
240.21 FIRE PROTECTION OUTSIDE MUNICIPALITY.
   (a)   Council hereby authorizes the Fire Department to provide fire
protection to any county, municipal corporation or township of this State upon
authorization of the officer or employee of the Department designated in
subsection (b) hereof.
   (b)   The Fire Chief or his or her designee is hereby designated as the
officer or employee of the Department to give such authorization as may be
appropriate pursuant to subsection (a) hereof.
(Res. 89-12-3. Passed 12-6-89.)
240.22 TERMINATION OF EMPLOYMENT WITHIN FIVE YEARS; REIMBURSEMENT OF CERTAIN
COSTS TO VILLAGE.
   (a)   Any full-time or part-time firefighter who leaves the Fire Department
or is terminated for any reason within five years of employment shall
recompense the Village for all monies expended for training, compensatory time
received and any tuition costs.
   (b)   The Fire Chief is hereby directed to have all fire personnel execute
an agreement as set forth in Exhibit "A" attached to original Ordinance 2000-9-
4, passed September 5, 2000, and incorporated herein by reference as if fully
rewritten herein.
(Ord. 2000-9-4. Passed 9-5-00.)
240.23 REQUIREMENTS FOR PART-TIME FIREFIGHTERS.
   All applicants for part-time firefighter positions in the Village must be
Firefighter I and II trained, Paramedic Certified and must reside within ten
miles of any Village boundary and retain those standards while employed.
(Ord. 2006-3-3. Passed 3-7-06; Ord. 2014-7-3. Passed 7-1-14.)
240.24 USER FEE FOR DELIVERY OF FIRE DEPARTMENT SERVICES.
   (a)   The Village of Valley View and the Fire Department shall initiate a
new user fee for the delivery of Fire Department services, personnel, supplies
and equipment to the scene of motor vehicle accidents. The rate of the user fee
shall be that which is the cost incurred which includes any services,
personnel, supplies and equipment and may fluctuate based on the services
provided.
   (b)   The user fee shall be filed to the motor vehicle insurance carrier,
representing an add-on-cost of the claim for damages to the vehicles, property
or injuries.
   (c)   The Mayor is authorized and directed to contract with a company
specializing in the billing of Fire Department Services for motor vehicle
accidents, for collection of such user fees as a result of Fire Department
services being provided.
   (d)   All amounts collected as a result of this amendment shall be placed
into a public safety, equipment and facilities fund as established by the
Clerk-Treasurer to be used exclusively for apparatus, equipment and facilities
for the Fire Department.
(Ord. 2006-12-4. Passed 12-5-06.)
