243.01 SERVICE DIRECTOR.
   (a)   Establishment. The office of full time Service Director is hereby
established.
   (b)   Appointment and term. The Service Director shall be appointed by the
Mayor subject to confirmation by Council. Such appointment shall be for a term
determined by Council, and, when appointed, shall serve until a successor is
appointed and qualified.
   (c)   Duties. It shall be the duty of the Director of Public Service to make
rules and regulations for the administration of the affairs under his or her
supervision. He or she shall manage and supervise all public lands and public
undertakings of the village. He or she shall have the management of all other
matters provided by Council with the public service thereof. The Director of
Public Service shall act as purchasing agent for the Service Department. The
Director of Public Service shall supervise the improvement and repair of
streets, avenues, alleys, lanes, lands, bridges, sidewalks, playgrounds,
sewers, drain ditches, culverts, streams and watercourses except those having
reference to the Department of Public Safety or as otherwise provided in Ohio
Revised Code Title VII.
   (d)   Compensation and benefits. The annual salary of the Service Director
shall be as determined by Council and shall include all the benefits enjoyed by
all other full-time employees (non-union).
(Ord. 2006-11-10. Passed 11-7-06.)
243.02 DIVISIONS. 
   There are hereby established two divisions within the Service Department
known as the Service Division and Grounds Keeping Division.
(Ord. 2006-11-10. Passed 11-7-06.)
243.03 SERVICE DIVISION.
   (a)   Service Department Foreman. There is hereby established the position
of Service Department Foreman, to be appointed by the Service Director and to
serve under the direction of the Service Director. The compensation for Service
Department Foreman shall be as determined by Council, plus all benefits being
enjoyed by full-time Service Department employees.
   (b)   Full-Time Service Division Workers. There is hereby established the
position of full-time Service Division workers to work under the supervision of
the Service Director. Eight such positions shall be established. Said employees
shall be compensated as determined by Council and shall also receive all
current benefits being enjoyed by full-time Service Department employees.
   (c)   Part-Time Service Division Workers. There is hereby established the
position of part-time Service Division workers to be hired by the Service
Director as needed and paid as determined by Council with no other benefits.
   (d)   Full-Time Mechanic. There is hereby established the position of full-
time mechanic, said position to be hired by the Service Director. The
compensation of the full-time mechanic shall be as determined by Council, plus
all current benefits being enjoyed by full-time Service Department employees.
   (e)   Seasonal snow plow drivers. There is hereby established the position
of seasonal snow plow drivers to be hired by the Service Director as needed and
paid as determined by Council, with no other benefits.
(Ord. 2006-11-10. Passed 11-7-06; Ord. 2011-12-38. Passed 2-7-12; Ord. 2013-10-
8. Passed 12-3-13.)
243.04 GROUNDS KEEPING DIVISION.
   (a)   Grounds Keeping Foreman. There is hereby established the position of
Grounds Keeping Foreman, to be appointed by the Director and to serve under the
direction of the Service Director. The compensation for said Grounds Keeping
Foreman shall be as determined by Council, plus all current benefits being
enjoyed by full-time Service Department employees.
   (b)   Full-Time Groundskeepers. There is hereby established the position of
full-time groundskeeper, to work under supervision of the Service Director.
Four such groundskeepers shall be employed. Said employees shall be compensated
as determined by Council and shall receive all current benefits being enjoyed
by full time Service Department employees.
   (c)   Part-Time Groundskeepers. There is hereby established the position of
seasonal part-time groundskeeper to be hired by the Service Director as needed
and paid as determined by Council with no other benefits.
(Ord. 2006-11-10. Passed 11-7-06; Ord. 2007-3-3. Passed 3-6-07)
243.05 SEASONAL ON-CALL SERVICE.
   (a)   Service Division Call Time.
      (1)   Summer (April 16 - November 14). The Service Division shall have
two employees on-call each day of the week to handle service calls. Such
employees shall receive two hours of straight time pay each day to be available
for such service calls.
      (2)   Weekday Call Time - Winter (November 15 - April 15). The Service
Division shall have employees on call each weekday. Weekday coverage shall
consist of four employees on call from 12:00 a.m. thru 7:30 a.m., and four
employees on call from 4:00 p.m. thru 12:00 a.m. Such employees shall receive
one hour straight time pay each day to be available for such service calls.
      (3)   Weekends and Holidays - Winter (November 15th - April 15th). The
Service Division shall have employees on-call each weekend and holiday. Weekend
and holiday coverage shall consist of four employees on call from 12:00 a.m.
thru 12:00 p.m. and four employees on call from 12:00 p.m. thru 12:00 a.m. Such
employees shall receive two hours straight time pay each day to be available
for such service.
   (b)   The Grounds Keeper Division Call Time.
      (1)   Summer (April 16 - November 14). The Grounds Keeper Division shall
have two employees on call each weekend day and holiday to handle service
calls. Such employees shall receive one hour straight time pay each day to be
available to such service calls.
      (2)   Winter (November 15 - April 15). The Grounds Keeper Division shall
have two employees on call each day of the week to handle service calls. Such
employees shall receive one hour straight time pay each day to be available for
such service calls.
      (3)   Weekends and Holidays - Winter (November 15 - April 15). The
Grounds Keeper Division shall have two employees on call each weekend day and
holiday to handle service calls. Such employees shall receive two hours
straight time pay each weekend day and holiday to be available for such service
calls.
   (c)   Days of work; holidays.
      (1)   Weekends constitute Saturday and Sunday only.
      (2)   Holidays are village-paid holidays.
      (3)   Weekdays are Monday thru Friday.
(Ord. 99-5-7. Passed 6-1-99; Ord. 2005-6-5. Passed 6-30-05; Ord. 2006-11-10.
Passed 11-7-06; Ord. 2011-12-38. Passed 2-7-12.)
243.06 SNOW PLOWING SERVICES FOR ELDERLY OR DISABLED RESIDENTS.
   (a)   To qualify for snow plowing, the following shall apply:
      (1)   The residence must be owner-occupied and the resident must be at
least sixty years of age or temporarily or permanently disabled.
      (2)   There is no other able-bodied person residing with the resident
capable of removing snow, be such person male or female, over sixteen years
old.
   (b)   Applications for snow plowing must be made yearly to the Mayor for
approval or disapproval.
   (c)   With respect to any particular property, the Mayor shall not make the
authorization referred to in subsection (b) hereof unless and until he or she
has determined that all Village roadways and the driveways and parking areas of
all public buildings have been cleared of snow.
   (d)   The Village will provide snow removal service only when, as determined
by the Service Department, there has been at least a cumulative four-inch
snowfall locally measured at the Town Hall by the Street Commissioner or
Service Department Foreman.
   (e)   The snow removal service, as provided for in this section, shall
consist of a standard size snow plow making two passes on the resident's
driveway, thereby making the public roads accessible to the resident's
premises.
   (f)   All residents who qualify for the snow removal service will be
expected to fully cooperate with the Service Department in providing the said
service, and any abuses, as determined by the Street Commissioner or Foreman,
will result in termination of said service.
   (g)   Both sides of a driveway shall be marked with tall indicator pegs or
marker stakes every twenty-five feet.
   (h)   The owner of the property to be cleared shall execute the following
statement: "In consideration of having the Village of Valley View clear my/our
driveway of my/our residence of snow, I/we hereby authorize the Village of
Valley View, its agents, servants and employees, to enter upon my/our property
with snow removal equipment at any reasonable time, and I/we hereby agree to
hold the Village of Valley View, its agents, servants and employees, harmless
for any property damage that might occur as a result of the entrance onto my/
our driveway, whether said damage is caused by an act of negligence or
otherwise."
   All signed statements shall be filed with the Clerk-Treasurer and shall be
open to public inspection during regular business hours.
   (i)   The Service Department will plow all driveways that meet the criteria
set forth in this section.
   (j)   Snow plowing will be performed with limited overtime as needed.
Measurable snow depths to implement residential driveway snow plowing shall be
determined by the Street Commissioner or Service Department Foreman. Staffing
and vehicles for the program will be determined by the Street Commissioner.
   (k)   Residents with extremely urgent conditions such as medical obligations
may contact the Mayor, Fire Chief, or Officer in Charge at the Fire Department
for exceptional emergency arrangements.
   (l)   The Mayor shall approve all applications.
(Ord. 2009-11-6. Passed 11-3-09; Ord. 2013-1-10. Passed 1-8-13; Ord. 2023-2-6.
Passed 4-4-23.)
243.07 LAWN MOWING SERVICE FOR ELDERLY OR DISABLED RESIDENTS.
   (a)   To qualify for lawn mowing service, the following shall apply:
      (1)   The resident must be at least 65 years of age or temporarily or
permanently disabled.
      (2)   The property being serviced by this program must be owner/occupied.
      (3)   There shall be an annual mowing fee of two hundred fifty dollars
($250.00) per resident due with the application.
      (4)   Residents who are eligible for the Cuyahoga County Home Energy
Assistance Program (HEAP) shall have the annual mowing fee waived. Residents
must show proof with the application that they have been accepted into the HEAP
program.
      (5)   There is no other able-bodied person residing with the resident
capable of mowing the resident's lawn, be such person male or female, over 16
years of age or older. The resident requesting lawn service shall sign an
affidavit stating there is no one living at the home between the ages of 16-65
capable of mowing the resident’s lawn.
      (6)   Medically impaired residents must present a doctors certificate or
other proof, stating the disability, along with an application, which shall be
kept on file.
   (b)   Application is for the calendar year 2019 and must be renewed
annually. All applications shall be submitted to the Clerk, and approved by the
Mayor.
   (c)   All residents that qualify for the lawn mowing service shall execute
the following statement: "In consideration of having the Village of Valley View
mow my/our lawn of my/our residence, I/we hereby authorize the Village of
Valley View, its agents, servants and employees to enter upon my/our property
with lawn mowing equipment at any reasonable time, and I/we hereby agree to
hold the Village of Valley View, its agents, servants and employees, harmless
for any property damage that may occur as a result of the entrance onto my/our
property, whether said damage is caused by an act of negligence or otherwise."
All signed statements shall be filed with the Clerk and shall be open to public
inspection during regular business hours.
   (d)   Lawn mowing services will be performed using Village equipment, no
earlier than 7:30 a.m. as scheduled by the Street Commissioner or Service
Department Foreman. Lawn size shall be limited to one acre per residence and
shall be limited to the discretion of the Street Commissioner or Service
Department Foremen.
(Ord. 2013-5-9. Passed 5-7-13; Ord. 2017-9-9. Passed 11-7-17; Ord. 2019-4-4.
Passed 4-2-19; Ord. 2019-5-12. Passed 5-7-19; Ord. 2021-5-5. Passed 5-4-21;
Ord. 2022-3-9. Passed 3-1-22.)

244.01 APPOINTMENT, TERM AND DUTIES.
   Council may provide for the employment of a Village Engineer, who shall be
appointed by the Mayor and confirmed by Council for a term of two years and who
shall serve until his successor is appointed and qualified. He shall render
such engineering services to the Village as Council authorizes and requires and
shall receive for his services such compensation by fees or otherwise as is
provided by ordinance or resolution.
(1965 Code § 145.01) (Ord. 2014-2-4. Passed 2-4-14.)
244.02 INSPECTOR.
   (a)   Qualifications. The Mayor and Clerk are hereby authorized to engage
the services of an Inspector who shall have a Class Two Waste Water Treatment
Plant Operator's license, issued to him by the State, and who shall not perform
any private inspection or maintenance of waste water treatment plants within
the Village while so engaged.
   (b)   Duties. The Inspector shall be under the direct supervision and
control of the Engineer. He shall make monthly inspections of mechanical waste
water treatment plants within the Village, except those plants which service
single-family units. He shall, at the time of his inspections, determine that
proper maintenance is being performed on such treatment plants and that such
plants are operating within the standards established by the Ohio Department of
Health. He shall conduct such standard chemical tests or analyses as are
necessary to determine the operating efficiency of such treatment plants and
shall perform whatever additional duties may be required by the Engineer, in
addition to those specified in
Chapter 1044 of the Streets, Utilities and Public Services Code.
   (c)   Compensation. The Inspector shall be paid the following fee per year
per each plant that he is directed to inspect by the Engineer:
      Gallons Per Day      Fee 
      1,000 to 5,000      $60.00
      5,001 to 20,000      84.00
      20,001 or more      108.00.
(Ord. 72-3-10. Passed 3-7-72.)

246.01 ESTABLISHMENT.
   The office of Street Commissioner of the Village is hereby established.
(Ord. 62-1-10. Passed 1-2-62.)
246.02 APPOINTMENT AND TERM.
   The Street Commissioner shall be appointed by the Mayor subject to
confirmation by Council. Such appointment shall be for a term of one year and
such officer, when appointed, shall serve until a successor is appointed and
qualified.
(Ord. 62-1-10. Passed 1-2-62.)
246.03 DUTIES.
   The duties of the Street Commissioner shall be such as are prescribed by
Ohio R.C. 735.32. In addition, the Street Commissioner shall be responsible for
keeping the roads and streets of the Village free from snow and shall perform
such other duties as Council may from time to time request.
(Ord. 62-1-10. Passed 1-2-62.)
246.04 ROAD CREW.
   (a)   The road crew shall consist of a foreman, nine full-time employees and
such part-time employees as may be needed from time to time.
(Ord. 00-1-10. Passed 1-4-00.)
   (b)   No appointment as a road crew employee shall be final until such
employee has satisfactorily completed a six-month probationary period. At the
end of six months, the Street Commissioner shall report to the Mayor that the
employee has or has not satisfactorily completed his or her six-month
probationary period. If he or she has, the appointment shall be final. If he or
she has not, the employee shall be discharged.
(Ord. 85-3-6. Passed 3-5-85.)
246.05 OVERTIME.
   (a)   The overtime pay for the Street Commissioner shall be one and one-half
times his or her hourly rate of pay.
   (b)   This section shall be retroactive to January 1, 1981.
(Ord. 81-2-8. Passed 2-3-81.)
CHAPTER 247
Recreation Department

   CROSS REFERENCES

Ch. 272
247.01 RECREATION DIRECTOR.
   (a)   Establishment. The office of full-time Recreation Director is hereby
established, effective January 1, 1998.
   (b)   Appointment and Term. The Recreation Director shall be appointed by
the Mayor, subject to confirmation by Council. Such appointment shall be for a
term determined by Council and, when appointed, shall serve until a successor
is appointed and qualified.
   (c)   Duties.
      (1)   The duties of the Director shall be as follows:
         A.   Supervise and coordinate all sports programs such as baseball,
soccer, basketball, bowling, etc., whatever the Recreation Board deems
necessary.
         B.   Serve as liaison between the Recreation Board, Council and the
Mayor.
         C.   Submit monthly written reports to Council concerning recreational
programs and activities taking place.
         D.   Act as purchasing agent for the Recreation Department.
         E.   Schedule the use of the Community Center, parks and park
pavilions for residents.
      (2)   Said position shall be full-time without overtime compensation for
hours worked in excess of forty hours.
   (d)   Compensation and Benefits. The annual salary of the Recreation
Director shall be as determined by Council from time to time and shall include
all the benefits enjoyed by all other full-time employees.
   (e)   Physical Examination Required. The Director shall be required to pass
a complete physical examination upon his or her appointment.
(Ord. 98-1-8. Passed 1-6-98; Ord. 2006-11-11. Passed 11-7-06.)
247.02 COMMUNITY CENTER; COMPOSITION AND COMPENSATION.
   (a)   Composition. The composition of the employees of the Community Center
shall be as follows:
      (1)   One full-time Recreation Director.
      (2)   One full-time Assistant Recreation Director.
      (3)   Eight part-time front desk clerks.
      (4)   Twelve part-time recreational aides and two part-time recreational
leaders.
      (5)   Two part-time maintenance employees. One part-time maintenance
technician, appointed by and working under the supervision of the Recreation
Director. The maintenance technician shall work not more than 24 hours per
week, subject to emergencies, as determined by the Recreation Director.
      (6)   One Seniors' coordinator.
      (7)   One part-time Youth Program Coordinator.
      (8)   Seasonal employees as follows:
         A.   Head counselors.
         B.   Camp counselors as needed to maintain the ratio, depending on
camp enrollment.
      (9)   Twelve residential transport persons divided into two separate
positions: transport and bus driver.
         A.   Residential transport persons paid as follows:
            1.   Bus drivers with proper certification required to drive a bus
shall be paid at their regular current rate, including on an emergency basis to
those employees who are not bus drivers ONLY.
         B.   All other transport persons shall be paid at the rate according
to the schedule referred to in subsection (b) below.
   (b)   Compensation. The compensation of the employees set forth in
subsection (a) hereof shall be as determined from time to time by Council. The
full-time Director shall not work or be paid for overtime. The part-time Youth
Program Coordinator shall not work more than thirty hours per week. All
salaries set forth in Ordinance 2005-6-23 shall remain in effect.
(Ord. 99-6-6. Passed 6-1-99; Ord. 2000-2-8. Passed 4-4-00; Ord. 2006-11-11.
Passed 11-7-06; Ord. 2007-5-10. Passed - -07; Ord. 2007-12-10. Passed 12-4-07;
Ord. 2013-5-5. Passed 5-7-13; Ord. 2014-9-31. Passed 9-16-14.)
247.03 PERMIT REQUIRED FOR USE OF CERTAIN RECREATION FACILITIES.
   (a)   A permit from the Village shall be required for the use of the
Village's basketball courts, tennis courts and baseball diamonds.
   (b)   Each resident household in the Village shall be entitled to a permit
for the use of the Village's basketball courts, tennis courts and baseball
diamonds.
   (c)   A permit holder shall be entitled to bring nonresidents onto the
Village's recreation facilities who will be playing basketball, tennis or
baseball with said resident or on said resident's team.
   (d)   Any person using the above-mentioned recreational facilities without a
permit must vacate the facilities upon the request of a permit holder who
desires to use said facilities.
(Ord. 96-9-8. Passed 10-1-96; Ord. 2006-11-11. Passed 11-7-06.)
247.04 GENERAL USE POLICY FOR RECREATION FACILITIES.
   (a)   The use of the new Community Center, and of the parks, recreation
areas and the Valley View Woods, shall be limited to residents of the Village
and their guests.
   (b)   Residents and their guests shall comply with the rules and regulations
adopted by the Recreation Board and amended from time to time.
   (c)   As used in this section, "resident" means a person who lives and is
domiciled within the Village and who does not maintain a permanent place of
abode elsewhere.
(Ord. 97-9-9. Passed 10-7-97; Ord. 2006-11-11. Passed 11-7-06.)
247.05 FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE FOR SUMMER CAMP PROGRAM.
   (a)   Residents of the Village who are in need of financial assistance to
participate in the Recreation Department's Summer Camp Program shall be
required to complete and submit a financial aid information and application
form in order to qualify for such assistance.
   (b)   Residents of the Village who are in need of financial assistance must
also be participants in the free and/or reduced lunch program as developed by
the Cuyahoga Heights School District.
(Ord. 99-5-4. Passed 5-4-99; Ord. 2006-11-11. Passed 11-7-06.)
247.06 PARK PATROL.
   (a)   There is hereby established a Park Patrol consisting of up to six
persons, as appointed by the Mayor.
   (b)   The persons appointed to the Park Patrol shall be considered part-time
and paid as determined by Council from time to time with no other benefits.
   (c)   The persons appointed to the Park Patrol shall work under the
supervision of the Recreation Director who will determine the work schedule and
duties schedule.
   (d)   The four parks shall be patrolled and maintained from April 1 through
October 31 of each year as follows:
      (1)   Weekends: 10:00 a.m. to 11:00 p.m.
      (2)   Weekdays (Monday through Friday): 4:00 p.m. to 11:00 p.m.
      (3)   All parks shall be patrolled at the discretion of the Recreation
Director or designee.
(Ord. 98-6-2. Passed 6-2-98; Ord. 2002-2-3. Passed 2-5-02; Ord. 2003-2-10.
Passed 3-4-03; Ord. 2007-3-4. Passed 3-6-07.)

248.01 PURCHASES.
   The Mayor, Clerk-Treasurer, Police Chief, Fire Chief, Street Commissioner
and Recreation Director are hereby authorized in the interim between Council
meetings, to direct the Village Clerk to make purchases for their respective
departments in an amount not in excess of two thousand dollars ($2,000). All
purchases in excess of two thousand dollars ($2,000) but not over five thousand
dollars ($5,000) shall be approved by the Finance Committee. If the Finance
Committee disapproves of any such expenditure, said disapproval shall be sent
to Council for review and final determination of said purchase. All purchases
in excess of five thousand dollars ($5,000) shall be reviewed first by the
Finance Committee and sent to Council with a recommendation, whether approved
or rejected immediately following the Finance Committee meeting. Final approval
for all purchases in excess of five thousand dollars ($5,000) shall be approved
by Council. Due to the fact that Council meets once a month, purchase orders
may be processed by the Clerk-Treasurer only when a majority of members
required for each individual purchase have contacted the Clerk-Treasurer in
such a manner that the Clerk-Treasurer can document the contact.
(Ord. 2008-12-6. Passed 1-6-09; Ord. 2014-8-3. Passed 8-19-14; Ord. 2020-2-14.
Passed 2-4-20.)

CHAPTER 249
Fire Department Testing and Promotion
249.01   Applications.
249.02   Examinations.
249.03   Review, tabulation and ranking of eligible applicants.
249.04   Additional credits.
249.05   Vacancies; eligibility for promotions; officers and Chief.
249.06   Probationary periods.
249.07   Reference to Policies and Procedures.
249.01   APPLICATIONS.
   (a)   Each applicant seeking an appointment in the Fire Department shall
file with the Clerk, by the deadline set by the Mayor, a formal application
which shall be furnished by the Clerk's office to any person that desires to
apply for an open position. Application forms shall be numbered and logged by
the Clerk's office. Any posting of results shall be by application number, not
by applicant's name. Applicants shall be notified on the application form that
those rendered unfit to perform the duties of the position desired, who have
been addicted to habitual use of alcohol or drugs, who have been convicted of a
felony, who have been dismissed from any public position, or have made any
false statements on the application are subject to dismissal of their
application. A background check shall be conducted by the Police Chief or
designee for convictions of felonies or misdemeanors on file for each applicant
and shall remain with the person's application. A background check is performed
before any testing commences.
   (b)   No person shall be eligible to take an examination for original
appointment as a fire fighter unless the person is at least 21 years of age and
no more than 40 years of age, has received a high school diploma, GED or its
equivalent, and is a natural born or naturalized citizen of the United States,
and has submitted a Personal Profile Questionnaire provided by the Village of
Valley View.
(Ord. 2019-4-6. Passed 4-2-19; Ord. 2024-9-5. Passed 9-10-24.)
249.02   EXAMINATIONS.
   (a)   Physical Agility Exam. Before taking the competitive written exam,
applicants for the new position shall be examined for ability to perform the
physical aspects and duties of the position. Applicants must provide proof of
agility certification at the time of turning in the application. Said
certificate shall be considered valid only if it is less then one year old. All
applicants must obtain and provide proof of agility certification before the
written exam per the requirements set forth in Section
240.19 . Note: Physical agility certificates for promotions are not required.
   (b)   Written Exam. After applicants have provided proof of physical agility
certification as per subsection (a), Council shall select an outside agency to
conduct competitive written exams for all candidates. The Mayor shall determine
a time and place for the written exam. Such written exam shall be practical in
nature and shall be directly related to those matters that fairly test the
capacity of the applicant to discharge the duties for which the test is
intended. In order to qualify for the psychological exam candidate must receive
a score of 70% on the written exam.
   (c)   Psychological Exam. After the written test results are tabulated by
Council, Council selects a medical consultant to fairly test the applicant's
ability to perform, mentally and psychologically, the duties of the position as
specified by Council through the consultant. After written and physical agility
tests are tabulated, the final results shall be posted.
(Ord. 2019-4-6. Passed 4-2-19; Ord. 2024-9-5. Passed 9-10-24.)
249.03   REVIEW, TABULATION AND RANKING OF ELIGIBLE APPLICANTS.
   (a)   After the written and physical exams, a review of the applicants shall
be scheduled, with a list of applicants considered to be eligible for the
available position(s) prepared by the Clerk, listed by number. The review shall
be by Mayor and Council in executive session. Council shall tally the written
test scores and add any credit points the applicant is entitled to according to
ordinance and list the applicants (by number) and their scores made. After the
scores are tabulated the candidate names shall be revealed by the clerk.
Council shall then determine by vote, the applicants chosen to proceed to the
remaining test procedures, and may choose up to ten candidates. (Psychological
exam, Section
249.02(c) and a list made. Determination of successful candidates shall include
all the attributes stated in the purpose of this chapter and the effects of
those attributes upon the community. After the psychological exam is completed,
the Mayor and the Fire Chief shall interview all final candidates. (A
conditional offer of appointment shall not be made until Council has reviewed
all examinations in total.)
   (b)   (1)   The final results of all tests shall be kept on file in the
office of the Mayor. Whenever there is a vacancy, the Mayor shall appoint from
the top ten candidates on the eligibility list. A person who has been
considered for appointment by the Mayor from an eligible list more than two
times to the same position shall be omitted from future consideration by the
Mayor.
      (2)   Council shall review the list of remaining applicants and determine
if the list is sufficient for appointment procedures. The eligibility list
shall be effective only for the department for which the list was originally
created and only for a period of two years from the initial written testing
date unless the requirements of this ordinance are revised within that time.
      (3)   Should a candidate refuse (in writing), for any reason, to accept
appointment in the Fire Department when first offered by the Mayor, such
candidate's name shall be removed from the eligibility list and such candidate
shall be ineligible to be reinstated on such list. After the expiration of said
eligible list, the candidate shall be eligible to reapply to take any
subsequent exam for initial appointment in the Fire Department.
(Ord. 2019-4-6. Passed 4-2-19; Ord. 2024-9-5. Passed 9-10-24.)
249.04   ADDITIONAL CREDITS.
   (a)   Residency Credit: New Appointments Only. An additional credit of one
point per year for continuous residency up to a maximum of five points
(provided the person receives a grade of 70% or better on the written test and
provides proof of agility certification) shall be given to all applicants for
initial appointment for maintaining their sole, bona-fide residence within the
Village. To qualify for this credit, the person must have maintained his or her
sole, bona-fide residence within the Village for a period of not less than one
year immediately prior to the examination. Proof of such residency shall be
submitted by the applicant at the time of application, and may be in the form
of proof of property ownership, proof of voter registration, proof of
registration with the U.S. post office or any other proof deemed as bona-fide.
   (b)   Fire Training Credit. An additional credit of five points shall be
given to all applicants for initial
appointment in the Fire Department (provided that the person receives a grade
of 70% or better on the written test and provides proof of agility
certification) if the applicant has a current and valid State of Ohio approved
Paramedic Certificate and a Fire Fighter Class I or II Certificate or its
equivalent. Proof of possession of the aforesaid certificates shall be
submitted by the applicant at the time of application. The aforesaid
certificates shall be maintained in good standing at the time of submission for
entitlement of the training credit.
   (c)   Graduate Credit. If a candidate receives the minimum 70% score on the
written exam and provides proof of agility certification, an additional credit
of five points shall be credited to the applicant if the applicant is a
graduate of an accepted four-year university or college in the United States.
Proof of graduation and degree shall be presented at the time of application.
For those applicants who do not have a four-year degree but possess an
associate's degree from an accepted two-year university or college, an
additional three points shall be credited to the applicant. Credit for
education higher than graduate degree shall not be given.
   (d)   Military Service Credit. If a candidate has a proof of agility
certificate and receives the minimum 70% on the written exam, a credit of five
points shall be awarded to the applicant for three years or more of military
service and proof of honorable discharge.
   (e)   If a candidate holds a position as a part-time Valley View
Firefighter/Paramedic a credit of one point for every two completed years of
service not to exceed five points, shall be awarded to the applicant.
(Ord. 2019-4-6. Passed 4-2-19; Ord. 2024-9-5. Passed 9-10-24.)
249.05   VACANCIES; ELIGIBILITY FOR PROMOTIONS; OFFICERS AND CHIEF.
   (a)   General. When there is a vacancy for new hires and Fire Chief within
the Fire Department, the Mayor shall place proper notice in the Village
newsletter as well as in a conspicuous place in the Town Hall and a newspaper
of general circulation within the community at least 30 days prior to
development of a candidate list. The notice and posting shall state a date and
time deadline for application. All applications (see Section
249.01 (a) and (b)) shall be forwarded to the Mayor and Council (by the Clerk)
for development of a competitive candidate list.
   (b)   In the case Council determines the needs to hold a competitive exam
for the position of Fire Chief, any fire fighter with a minimum of ten years'
service, and any officer, Lieutenant or above with a minimum of 36 months
experience (any includes firefighters and officers outside the Village of
Valley View Fire Department) shall be eligible to take a competitive written
exam and be eligible for promotion to the position of Fire Chief. All
applicants must possess a current Paramedic Certificate and a Firefighter Class
1 or 2 Certificate. Council shall use the Ohio Fire Chiefs Written Exam
followed by the Ohio Fire Chiefs Assessment. The test shall consist of 40%
written exam and 60% assessment from the designated assessment center. A person
desiring to apply for an available position of Fire Chief shall complete an
application as described in Section
249.01 and become eligible to take the exam as described in Section
249.02. A passing grade of 70% is required, on the written exam to be eligible
to sit for the assessment center. In the case where not more than one person
applies to take the exam for the position of Fire Chief, the Mayor may waive
the testing requirement.
   (c)   The Mayor and Council shall review and evaluate the test results, sent
via certified mail, presented to Council by the Clerk or Mayor. After
discussion of the test results, Mayor and Council shall invite as many as three
candidates to an interview to be held at a time and place designated by the
Mayor. Mayor and Council shall then interview the candidates for a desired
character and traits desirable for the position and by majority vote, designate
a successful candidate or at that time decide to advertise for the position.
   (d)   (1)   In the case of a vacancy in the position of Lieutenant, full-
time Valley View Firefighters with a minimum of four years of service, or
Valley View Firefighters with a minimum of ten years of full and part-time
combined experience at the Valley View Fire Department shall be eligible to
take a competitive written exam to be eligible for promotion. Council shall use
the Ohio Fire Chiefs Written Exam followed by the Ohio Fire Chiefs Assessment.
The test shall consist of 60% written exam and 40% assessment from the
designated assessment center. A passing cumulative grade of 70% is required on
the written exam to be eligible to sit for the assessment center.
      (2)   An additional credit of one point per year of service is allowed
after five years and up to 15 completed years with a maximum of ten points
allowed, for all promotions except Fire Chief.
      (3)   An additional credit of five points shall be credited to the
applicant if the applicant is a graduate of an accepted four-year university or
college in the United States. Proof of graduation and degree shall be presented
at the time of application. For those applicants who do not have a four-year
degree but possess an associate's degree from an accepted two-year university
or college, an additional three points shall be credited to the applicant.
Credit for education higher than graduate degree shall not be given.
      (4)   All promotions shall be made from one of the top three candidates
after adding up all the test scores including any credits received. Appointment
to the position shall be made with the consideration of written recommendations
from the Fire Chief.
(Ord. 2019-4-6. Passed 4-2-19; Ord. 2024-9-5. Passed 9-10-24.)
249.06   PROBATIONARY PERIODS.
   (a)   All initial appointments in the Fire Department shall extend for a
probationary period of one year from date of original hire and promotion. Such
period may be extended by the Mayor with approval of Council for good cause for
a period not to exceed an additional six months.
   (b)   No initial appointment to Fire Fighter shall be deemed final until the
appointee has successfully served his or her probationary period. At the end of
the probationary period, the Chief of the Fire Department will transmit to the
Mayor a record of the employee's service, together with a recommendation as to
whether the employee has satisfactorily served his or her probationary period.
The Mayor shall then make a determination as to whether the appointee has
satisfactorily served the probationary period. If such service is satisfactory,
the appointee shall continue within rank. If the recommendation of the Mayor
and Fire Chief concur as to the unsatisfactory probationary period, the Mayor
shall cause a written notice of an unsatisfactory probationary period, the
Mayor shall cause a written notice of an unsatisfactory probationary and a
statement of such shall be issued to the employee as to his/her termination of
employment.
(Ord. 2019-4-6. Passed 4-2-19; Ord. 2024-9-5. Passed 9-10-24.)
249.07   REFERENCE TO POLICES AND PROCEDURES.
   According to the ordinances of the Village of Valley View and the Ohio
Revised Code, and the information contained herein regarding the testing
program established by the Village of Valley View, other aspects of employment
are regulated by the Policies and Procedures Manual established by ordinance
and all matters not referring to Fire Department testing procedures shall refer
to said manual.
(Ord. 2019-4-6. Passed 4-2-19; Ord. 2024-9-5. Passed 9-10-24.)

250.14   Dental insurance.

250.01 BONDS.
   (a)   The Mayor shall give bond in the sum of four thousand dollars
($4,000), with surety to be approved by Council.
   (b)   The Clerk-Treasurer shall give bond in the sum of twenty thousand
dollars ($20,000), with surety to be approved by the Mayor.
   (c)   The Chief of Police shall give bond in the sum of four thousand
dollars ($4,000), with surety to be approved by Council.
   (d)   The Police Lieutenant shall give bond in the sum of one thousand
dollars ($1,000).
   (e)   The Police Captain shall give bond in the sum of one thousand dollars
($1,000).
   (f)   Each full-time Patrolman shall give bond in the sum of one thousand
dollars ($1,000).
   (g)   The Detective shall give bond in the sum of four thousand dollars
($4,000).
   (h)   Each Sergeant shall give bond in the sum of one thousand dollars
($1,000).
   (i)   Each part-time Patrolman and each Special Policeman shall give bond in
the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000).
   (j)   The Jailor/Administrator shall give bond in the sum of four thousand
dollars ($4,000).
   (k)   The Clerk of Courts shall give bond in the sum of four thousand
dollars ($4,000).
   (l)   The Clerk Secretary shall give bond in the sum of two thousand dollars
($2,000).
   (m)   The Building Inspector shall give bond in the sum of one thousand
dollars ($1,000).
(Ord. 94-1-7. Passed 1-4-94.)
250.02 VACATIONS AND HOLIDAYS.
   (a)   All full-time employees of the Village shall be entitled to the
following vacations, holidays, personal days and birthdays: At the time or
times agreeable to the Mayor, department heads and the employee, the full-time
employees are entitled to ten working days vacation during the calendar year
after their first year of continuous service, eleven working days off after
completing five years of service, twelve working days off after completing six
years of service, thirteen working days off after completing seven years of
service, fourteen working days off after completing eight years of service,
fifteen days off after completing nine years of service, sixteen working days
off after completing ten years of service, seventeen working days off after
completing eleven years of service, eighteen working days off after completing
twelve years of service, nineteen working days off after completing thirteen
years of service, twenty days off after completing fourteen years of service,
twenty one working days off after completing fifteen years of service, twenty-
two working days off after completing sixteen years of service, twenty-three
working days off after completing seventeen years of service, twenty-four
working days off after completing eighteen years of service, twenty-five
working days off after completing nineteen years of service, and twenty-five
working days off after completing twenty years of service. In addition to the
aforesaid vacation period, each full-time employee shall be entitled to the
following nine paid holidays: New Year's Day, President's Day, Good Friday,
Memorial Day, Independence Day, Labor Day, Columbus Day, Thanksgiving Day,
Christmas Day and four personal days, one of which is to be said employee's
birthday, provided, however, that the personal days off must be approved by the
department head, and the department head's personal days off must be approved
by the Mayor, and provided, further, that an employee will use his or her
birthday and three personal days as "time off" prior to November 1 of said
year, unless the employee's birthday is in November and December of said year.
Effective January 1, 2003, for all full-time non-union employees, the personal
days will count toward time worked for the purpose of calculating overtime.
   (b)   The following personnel must take their holidays as time off:
department heads, including the Chief of Police, the Street Commissioner, the
Building Inspector, the Recreation Director, the Janitor-Jailer, the Clerk of
Courts, the Senior Clerk, the Junior Clerk and clerical personnel.
(Ord. 2003-3-7. Passed 3-18-03.)
   (c)   All full-time employees who are required to work during their vacation
periods shall be compensated at a rate of one and a half times their hourly
rate retroactive to December 22, 1985.
(Ord. 86-3-8. Passed 3-4-86.)
250.03 TRAVEL EXPENSES; MAYOR'S AUTOMOBILE EXPENSES.
   (a)   The actual traveling expenses of the Mayor, members of Council, the
Engineer, the Solicitor or other officials of the Village shall be paid to such
officials in all cases where they are required to travel beyond the limits of
the Village in the performance of their duties. Such traveling expenses shall
be carefully itemized and logged and shall be submitted to Council for its
approval before payment.
(Ord. 72-10-3. Passed 10-3-72; Ord. 2011-9-12. Passed 11-1-11.)
   (b)   In addition to his or her regular compensation, the Mayor is hereby
entitled to automobile fuel expense limited to one thousand five hundred
dollars ($1,500) annually, separate from approved travel expenses.
(Ord. 91-12-26. Passed 1-10-92; Ord. 2011-9-12. Passed 11-1-11.)
   (c)   This section shall provide for mileage allowance for employees at the
rate of fifty-eight point five (58.5) cents per mile for the use of his/her
vehicle while on duty and/or while performing certain duties, conferences
relating to his/her position. A detailed log, a copy of which is hereby
attached, must be completed by the individual for documentation.
(Ord. 2008-4-2. Passed 4-1-08; Ord. 2014-9-12. Passed 9-16-14; Ord. 2022-3-5.
Passed 3-1-22.)
250.04 CLOTHING ALLOWANCES.
   (a)   Any monetary allowance authorized by Council from time to time for the
purchase of required clothing for the Chief of Police, Patrolmen and part-time
Patrolmen, the Fire Chief and full-time and volunteer firemen, shall be in
addition to their regular compensation and compensation provided for in this
chapter.
(Ord. 76-11-5. Passed 1-18-77.)
   (b)   Commencing July 1, 2011, the following clothing allowance is
established for the employees of the Village:
      (1)   Newly hired part-time police recruits will receive compensation
sufficient to pay for all clothing and equipment set forth in Exhibit “A” which
is attached as an appendix to this chapter. This shall be their clothing
allowance for the first year of employment.
      (2)   Part-time members of the Police Department, excepting newly hired
recruits, are to receive five hundred dollars ($500.00) per year clothing
allowance.
      (3)   Newly hired part-time firemen will receive compensation sufficient
to pay for all clothing and equipment set forth in Exhibit "B" attached as an
appendix to this chapter. All other necessary equipment will be provided by the
Village. This shall be their clothing allowance for the first year of
employment.
      (4)   Part-time members of the Fire Department, excepting newly hired
recruits, are to receive four hundred dollars ($400.00) per year clothing
allowance.
      (5)   Effective July 1, 2011 all full-time service and groundskeepers
employees are to receive seven hundred dollars ($700.00) per year clothing
allowance with the following stipulation: part-time service and part-time
groundskeepers employees will receive two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) after
being employed for six months and two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for every
future six months they are employed, up to a maximum of five hundred dollars
($500.00) per year.
      (6)   All employees shall use their clothing allowance within the current
calendar year. Employees who overspend their allowance shall re-pay the Village
within the thirty days of the billing by the Village.
(Ord. 2011-12-18. Passed 12-6-11.)
   (c)   When a full-time member of any of the above departments also performs
services as a part-time member of the department in which he or she is employed
full time, then he or she will receive only the clothing allowance set forth
for full-time employees.
   (d)   When a full-time member of a department is also a part-time employee
of one of the other departments and the clothing required is different for the
part-time job, then that employee will receive both the full-time allowance and
the part-time allowance.
   (e)   The supervisor or officer-in-charge shall have the authority to send
any employee or officer home for the day if he or she reports to work not
properly dressed in the required uniform or not properly groomed. Said employee
will not receive compensation for that particular day.
(Ord. 94-12-29. Passed 12-6-94; Ord. 2000-7-9. Passed 7-11-00.)
250.05 LONGEVITY COMPENSATION.
   (a)   General Guidelines.
      (1)   Any employee of the Village who is employed at more than one
position which provides for longevity shall be entitled to only one longevity
compensation which shall be the greater amount of the compensation allowed.
      (2)   For the purpose of counting years of service, full-time service
shall include only full-time employment.
      (3)   Part-time employment years cannot be credited towards full-time
employment years required for full-time longevity compensation.
      (4)   Part-time employment years in one position shall not be credited to
part-time years required for part-time longevity compensation in another
position.
      (5)   Full-time employment years in one position shall not be credited to
part-time years required for part-time longevity compensation in another
position.
(Ord. 88-3-24. Passed 3-1-88.)

250.06 HOURS OF WORK AND OVERTIME.
   (a)   Except for emergency special assignments, not more than eight hours
shall constitute a day of work and not more than forty hours shall constitute a
week of work on which regular compensation is based. Full-time members of the
Police Department performing work in excess of forty hours per week shall be
compensated at the rate of time and one-half. For work performed on any paid
holiday, full-time police officers and firemen shall receive compensation at a
rate of one and one-half times their regularly established rate of
compensation.
(Ord. 78-2-5. Passed 2-7-78.)
   (b)   Except as provided in subsection (d) hereof, the following employees
are hereby exempted from overtime requirements:
      (1)   The Chief of Police;
      (2)   The Deputy Chief of Police;
      (3)   The Chief of the Fire Department;
      (4)   The Inspector of Buildings; and
      (5)   The Street Commissioner.
   (c)   The employees exempted in subsection (b) hereof shall be paid for
holidays worked at a rate of one and one-half times their hourly rate.
(Ord. 86-4-3. Passed 4-1-86.)
   (d)   Whenever the Chief of the Fire Department is required to report to the
station before his or her usual starting time and is out on a fire or ambulance
run after his or her usual quitting time, he or she shall receive overtime pay.
Such overtime pay shall not be allowable if he or she is called to the station
after he or she has returned to his or her home. In all other respects
subsections (b) and (c) hereof, relating to the Chief of the Fire Department
being exempt from overtime pay, shall remain in full force and effect.
(Ord. 88-3-20. Passed 3-1-88.)
   (e)   Service and Recreation Department employees who work in excess of
thirty-two hours during a week commencing on Sunday and ending on Saturday at
12:00 midnight, in which a nonworking eight-hour holiday has been credited,
shall receive overtime pay for such excess hours, the holiday nonworking eight
hours having been credited towards the forty-hour requirement for overtime.
(Ord. 94-11-4. Passed 11-16-94; Ord. 2013-2-4. Passed 2-5-13.)
250.07 HOSPITALIZATION.
   (a)   The Chief of Police and each full-time Patrolman shall receive
hospitalization insurance coverage as deemed appropriate by Council.
(Ord. 66-1-7. Passed 1-11-66.)
   (b)   In addition to his or her regular compensation, the Mayor shall be
entitled to hospitalization.
(Ord. 91-12-26. Passed 1-10-92.)
   (c)   All employees of the Village who are covered by its hospitalization
plan shall be required to pay fifty dollars ($50.00) per month towards the
amount required for their individual hospitalization. Said amount shall be a
pre-tax deduction from the employee's pay.
(Ord. 94-7-9. Passed 7-27-94; Ord. 2005-5-3. Passed 5-3-05.)
   (d)   Unless otherwise provided, elected officials of the Village shall have
the right to purchase the same type of hospitalization insurance as the Village
purchases for its employees, provided, however, that said elected officials pay
the monthly premium cost to the Clerk-Treasurer one month prior to the payment
date therefor.
(Ord. 97-2-5. Passed 2-4-97.)
250.08 MINIMUM PAY FOR FIRES.
   In computing compensation for fires, two hours shall be considered as the
minimum to be paid to any fireman or officer and any fraction of an hour shall
be considered an hour.
(1965 Code § 143.11)
250.09 PETTY CASH FUNDS.
   (a)   Except as otherwise provided in subsection (b) hereof, the petty cash
fund of the Police Department shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) and the
petty cash fund of the Clerk-Treasurer shall be fifty dollars ($50.00). All
items paid out of such petty cash funds shall be upon pay-out requests signed
by an authorized person in the Police Department or by the Clerk, as to each of
their funds, by written pay-out memoranda, so that a proper accounting may be
made of such funds and so that the expenses of the Village may be charged to
the appropriate funds and accounts. Such petty cash accounts shall be
established by payment to each of the departments of those petty cash amounts
so designated, which shall be replenished from time to time by reimbursement
for the pay-out memoranda from such accounts by the turning over of such
memoranda, properly identified and authorized, to the Village Treasurer.
(Ord. 89-5-2. Passed 5-2-89; Ord. 93-6-5. Passed 6-1-93; Ord. 2002-6-5. Passed
6-4-02.)
   (b)   There is hereby created a special petty cash fund which shall be used
in connection with the payment of traffic fines and which shall be administered
by the Chief of Police. The Clerk-Treasurer is hereby directed to place two
hundred dollars ($200.00) in said fund.
(Ord. 92-28. Passed 2-4-92.)
   (c)   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Subsection (c) was repealed by Ordinance 97-9-16,
passed September 23, 1997.)
   (d)   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Subsection (d) was repealed by Ordinance 97-9-16,
passed September 23, 1997.)
   (e)   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Subsection (e) was repealed by Ordinance 97-9-16,
passed September 23, 1997.)
   (f)   There is hereby established a special petty cash fund of one hundred
dollars ($100.00) for the Community Center to be operated by the Recreation
Director. Such petty cash account shall be established by payment to the
Recreation Department of those petty cash amounts so designated, which shall be
replenished from time to time by reimbursement for the pay-out memoranda from
such accounts by the turning over of such memoranda, properly identified and
authorized, to the Clerk-Treasurer. All items paid out of such petty cash funds
shall be written pay-out memoranda, so that a proper accounting may be made of
such funds and so that the expenses of the Village may be charged to the
appropriate funds and accounts. Such petty cash amounts shall be established by
payment to the Director of those petty cash amounts so designated, which shall
be replenished from time to time by reimbursement for the pay-out memoranda
from such accounts by the turning over of such memoranda, properly identified
and authorized, to the Clerk-Treasurer.
(Ord. 98-1-2. Passed 1-6-98.)
250.10 SICK LEAVE PAY.
   (a)   It shall be the policy of the Village that, upon their retirement,
full-time and permanent part-time employees of the Village shall receive
payment for their unused sick leave to a maximum of ninety days at the rate of
pay at the time of retirement. Fifteen years of continuous service shall be
required for an employee to be considered retired under this section.
   (b)   It shall be the policy of the Village that, upon their retirement,
full-time firefighters of the Village, with the exception of the Fire Chief,
shall receive payment for their unused sick leave to a maximum of 720 hours at
the rate of pay at the time of retirement. Fifteen years of continuous service
shall be required for an employee to be considered retired under this section.
   (c)   Each full-time firefighter, with the exception of the Fire Chief,
shall receive sick leave credit based on 4.6 hours of sick leave for every
eighty hours of work, provided that full-time firefighters are on the twenty-
four to forty-eight hour work schedule.
   (d)   Full-time and permanent part-time employees, with a minimum of five
years continuous service, with the exception of twenty-four to forty-eight hour
shift full-time firefighters, upon resignation or discharge without cause,
shall receive one-third of their unused sick leave to a maximum of fifty days
at the rate of pay at the time of termination.
   (e)   Provisional appointees, or those who render temporary, part-time,
seasonal or intermittent service, shall be excluded from the benefits of this
section. Any seasonal employees including, but not limited to, Service
Recreation, Park Patrol and Camp Counselors, shall not earn any sick time. No
part-time employee hired after March 18, 2003, shall earn any sick time.
(Ord. 2003-3-6. Passed 3-18-03.)
250.11 CLERK'S ANNUAL REPORT TO COUNCIL RE COMPENSATION.
   (a)   Annually, on or before the date of Council's first regular meeting in
March, the Clerk of the Village shall submit to Council a written report of the
gross amount of all compensation paid by the Village to each elected or
appointed official or employee of the Village, during the preceding calendar
year, as reported by the Village to the Internal Revenue Service of the U.S.
Department of the Treasury.
   (b)   Where an official or employee received employment benefits in addition
to the gross compensation referred to in subsection (a) hereof, e.g. paid
vacation time, paid hospitalization insurance, a uniform allowance, etc., the
Clerk shall place an asterisk after the amount referred to in subsection (a)
hereof and shall note upon such report the fact that such asterisk indicates
the existence of additional employment benefits.
   (c)   The report compiled by the Clerk shall, upon its presentation to
Council, become a public document and shall be distributed to residents of the
Village in such manner as Council, by motion, directs.
   (d)   The Clerk shall certify in writing to Council that the report was
compiled from the books and records of the Village and that to the best of the
Clerk's knowledge it is correct.
(Ord. 77-5-5. Passed 5-3-77.)
250.12 INJURED-ON-DUTY LEAVE; SICK LEAVE CREDITS.
   (a)   Injured on-Duty Leave.
      (1)   As used in this subsection, "injury-on-duty" means any physical
damage or illness which occurs as a result of an employee's discharge of his or
her duty.
      (2)   All full-time employees injured or incapacitated as provided herein
shall be entitled to a leave of absence with pay, subject to the following
conditions:
         A.   If the employee is absent from work for more than seven
consecutive days, he or she shall file for workers' compensation.
         B.   Compensation for the first twelve weeks received by the employee
from the Ohio Bureau of Workers' Compensation as a reimbursement for wages for
a period the employee was carried on injured-on-duty status shall be paid over
to the Village. After twelve weeks, the employee shall continue to collect
workers' compensation and the Village shall pay the difference between the
employee's salary and the workers' compensation.
         C.   The employee shall be compensated until eligible for a disability
pension or for a maximum of two years, whichever is the lesser.
      (3)   All part-time employees injured or incapacitated as provided herein
shall be entitled to a leave of absence with pay, subject to the following
conditions:
         A.   If the employee is absent from work for more than seven
consecutive days, he or she shall file for workers' compensation.
         B.   An injured part-time employee's compensation shall be based upon
the Workers' Compensation Law of the State.
         C.   The injured part-time employee shall be paid as soon as possible
by the Village according to the Workers' Compensation Law.
         D.   All compensation received by the part-time employee from the
Bureau of Workers' Compensation, for wages for the period the employee was
carried on injured-on-duty status, shall be paid over to the Village.
      (4)   There is hereby established an Injured-On-Duty Review Board
consisting of one member of the Police Department, one member of the Fire
Department, one member of the Road Department (Road Crew), selected by the
respective Department Heads, and four members of Council elected by Council.
      (5)   If written objections are filed with the Mayor by any department
member or member of Council concerning an employee's eligibility for payment
under this section, a hearing shall be conducted by the Injured-On-Duty-Review-
Board to hear such objections. The party whose eligibility is in question may
call witnesses to testify on his or her behalf and the Board may call witnesses
to testify if desired. The employee and /or the Board may call expert witnesses
to testify if they so desire.
(Ord. 84-6-2. Passed 6-5-84.)
   (b)   Sick Leave Credits.
      (1)   Sick leave credits of an employee who is injured during the
performance of his or her duties within the scope of his or her employment
shall not be reduced for any period of time that he or she is absent from work
because of such service connected injury. The term "injury" means physical
damage resulting from an accident and also includes heart attacks or failures,
strokes or physical or mental illnesses or diseases if the employee furnishes a
certificate from a physician that such injury is service connected.
      (2)   In the event of a dispute as to whether an injury is service
connected within the meaning of this section, such dispute shall be submitted
to a Board of Appeals consisting of the Mayor and two members of Council to be
selected by Council. If the injured person is a member of the Fire Department,
such Board shall be increased to include two firefighters to be selected by the
members of the Fire Department. If the injured person is a member of the Police
Department, such Board shall be increased to include two policemen to be
selected by the members of the Police Department. The decision of said Board
shall be final and conclusive.
      (3)   In the event that one or both of the Fire Department or Police
Department representatives are unable to serve on such Board, Council shall
then fill such vacancy by selecting one or two additional Council members.
(Ord. 79-4-5. Passed 4-10-79.)
250.13 LIMITATIONS ON EXPENDITURES FOR POLICE, FIRE AND ROAD DEPARTMENTS.

      (3)   The Inspector of Buildings; and

250.16 FUNERAL LEAVE.
   (a)   All full-time employees shall be entitled to three working days to
attend funerals for their spouse, children, parents, brothers, sisters, mother-
in-law, father-in-law, grandparents and grandchildren.
   (b)   Each full-time firefighter, with the exception of the Fire Chief,
shall be entitled to one twenty- four hour tour of duty off with pay to attend
the funeral of his or her spouse, children, parents, brothers, sisters, mother-
in-law, father-in-law, grandparents and grandchildren.
(Ord. 94-6-5. Passed 6-7-94.)
250.17 PRE-EMPLOYMENT PHYSICAL EXAMINATIONS AND EVALUATIONS.
   (a)   All prospective full-time and part-time employees, with the exception
of part-time seasonal high school students and playground supervisors, shall be
required to submit to a physical examination and/or evaluation from St. Alexis
Occupational Health Service or from any doctor of medicine or osteopathy
selected by Council.
   (b)   If the designated physician determines, after obtaining the results of
the pre-employment physical examination or evaluation, that the physical
condition of the prospective employee would not enable him or her to perform
the job requirements set forth in the Village job description, then that
determination shall be final and such prospective employee shall not be hired.
(Ord. 86-12-8. Passed 12-16-86.)
250.18 DEFERRED COMPENSATION.
   (a)   The Village hereby adopts a plan under the Ohio Public Employees
Deferred Compensation Program and extends to all eligible employees the
opportunity to join.
   (b)   The Mayor is hereby authorized and directed to execute an agreement
with the Ohio Public Employees Deferred Compensation Board on terms and
conditions which the Mayor determines are in the best interest of the Village.
Such agreement shall authorize the Board to offer a plan under the Program to
all eligible employees of the Village and thereafter to administer the plan on
behalf of such employees.
(Ord. 87-5-2. Passed 5-5-87.)
250.19 PICK UP OF PERS CONTRIBUTION.
   (a)   Effective March 17, 1991, the full amount of the statutorily required
contributions to the Public Employees Retirement System of Ohio and the Police
and Firemen's Disability and Pension Fund shall be withheld from the gross pay
of each person within any of the classes established in subsection (b) hereof
and shall be "picked up" (assumed and paid to the Public Employees Retirement
System of Ohio and the Police and Firemen's Disability and Pension Fund) by the
Village of Valley View. This "pick up" by the Village of Valley View is, and
shall be designated as, public employee contributions and shall be in lieu of
contributions to the Public Employees Retirement System of Ohio and the Police
and Firemen's Disability and Pension Fund by each person within any of the
classes established in subsection (b) hereof. No person subject to this "pick
up" shall have the option of choosing to receive the statutorily required
contribution to the Public Employees Retirement System of Ohio and the Police
and Firemen's Disability and Pension Fund directly instead of having it "picked
up" by the Village of Valley View or of being excluded from the "pick up". The
Village of Valley View shall, in reporting and making remittance to the Public
Employees Retirement System of Ohio and the Police and Firemen's Disability and
Pension Fund, report that the public employees' contribution for each person
subject to this "pick up" has been made as provided by statute.
   (b)   The "pick up" by the Village of Valley View provided by this section
shall apply to all persons who are employees of the Village of Valley View and
who are contributing members of the Public Employees Retirement System of Ohio
and the Police and Firemen's Disability and Pension Fund.
   (c)   The Village's method of payment of salary and provision of fringe
benefits to employees who are participants in PERS and the Police and Firemen's
Disability and Pension Fund are hereby modified as follows, in order to provide
for a salary reduction pick-up of employee contributions to PERS and the Police
and Firemen's Disability and Pension Fund.
   (d)   The total salary for each employee shall be the salary otherwise
payable under Village policies. Such total salary of each employee shall be
payable by the Village in two parts: (1) deferred salary; and (2) cash salary.
An employee's deferred salary shall be equal to that percentage of that
employee's total salary which is required from time to time, by PERS and the
Police and Firemen's Disability and Pension Fund, to be paid as an employee
contribution by that employee, and shall be paid by the Village to PERS and the
Police and Firemen's Disability and Pension Fund on behalf of that employee as
a pick up and in lieu of the PERS and Police and Firemen's Disability and
Pension Fund employee contribution otherwise payable by that employee. An
employee's cash salary shall be equal to that employee's total salary less the
amount of the pick up for that employee, and shall be payable, subject to
applicable payroll deductions, to that employee. The Village shall compute and
remit its employer contributions to PERS and the Police and Firemen's
Disability and Pension Fund based upon an employee's total annual salary.
   The total combined expenditures of the Village for such employee's total
salaries payable under applicable Village policies and the collective
bargaining agreement with union employees (including pick up amounts), and the
pick-up provisions of this section shall not be greater than the amounts it
would have paid for those items had this provision not been in effect.
   (e)   The employee contribution pick up shall be included in the employee's
total annual salary for the purpose of computing daily rate of pay, for
determining paid salary adjustments to be made due to absence, or for any
similar purpose.
   (f)   The Clerk-Treasurer is hereby authorized and directed to implement the
provisions of this section to effect the "pick up" of the statutorily required
contributions to the PERS and the Police and Firemen's Disability and Pension
Fund for those persons reflected in subsection (b) hereof so as to enable them
to obtain the resulting Federal and State tax deferments and other benefits.
(Ord. 91-33. Passed 3-5-91.)
250.20 REIMBURSEMENT OF EXPENSES FOR SEMINARS, CONFERENCES AND SCHOOLS.
   (a)   Commencing October 1, 1995, each member of Council, the Clerk-
Treasurer and the Mayor are each entitled to six hundred dollars ($600.00) per
twelve months for expenses incurred for attending seminars, conferences and
schools which are related to the operation of a municipal government.
   (b)   Each official attending a seminar, conference or school shall obtain
receipts of all expenses and present such receipts to the Clerk-Treasurer for
payment. If funds are needed prior to attending said seminars, conferences or
schools, the Clerk-Treasurer may pay the tuition or fees directly to the
seminars, conferences or schools.
   (c)   Approval by the Finance Committee or Council shall not be required for
permission to attend any Municipal seminar, conference or school, nor shall
Finance Committee approval of expenses be required for the same.
   (d)   The funds necessary are hereby or will be appropriated.
(Ord. 95-9-9. Passed 9-19-95.)
250.21 BACKGROUND CHECKS FOR NEWLY HIRED PATROLMEN AND FIREFIGHTERS;
PSYCHOLOGICAL AND POLYGRAPH TESTING.
   (a)   A background check shall be made on any new hire (full and part-time)
of the Police and Fire Departments.
   (b)   Background checks shall be made by an independent consultant whose
reports shall be made to the Mayor, with copies provided to the members of
Council.
   (c)   All newly hired patrolmen and firefighters, full and part-time, shall
also receive psychological testing and a polygraph test. This testing shall
also be required of part-time patrolmen and firefighters who receive full-time
appointments to the Police and Fire Departments.
   (d)   Reports shall be discussed in an executive session.
   (e)   Background checks shall be confidential and shall not be disclosed to
anyone other than the Mayor, members of Council, the Clerk-Treasurer, the Law
Director and the Assistant Law Director/Prosecutor.
   (f)   Council shall determine the independent consultant who will perform
the testing.
(Ord. 96-2-9. Passed 3-5-96.)
250.22 USE OF VILLAGE VEHICLES BY POLICE CHIEF AND FIRE CHIEF.
   (a)   The Police Chief and Fire Chief shall each be provided with an
automobile at the Village's expense and maintenance.
   (b)   The Police Chief and the Fire Chief are hereby authorized to use such
vehicles while driving to and from their place of employment and are further
authorized to use the vehicles while driving miscellaneous and minor personal
errands.
   (c)   The Clerk-Treasurer is hereby authorized to enter into appropriate
financial arrangements to carry out the provisions of this section.
(Ord. 99-4-9. Passed 6-1-99; Ord. 2011-1-3. Passed 1-4-11; Ord. 2011-6-4.
Passed 6-7-11.)
250.23 TELEPHONE USAGE POLICY.
   (a)   Cellular Phones, Nextel Phones, Pagers and Desk Phones. Village issued
cellular telephones, pagers, desk telephones and computers are intended for
official business use. While occasional personal use is permitted, it must be
responsible and it must be clearly incidental to business use. Employees must
reimburse the Village for any costs associated with personal use of Village
issued telephones.
   (b)   Cellular and/or Nextel Telephone Assignment and Use. Cellular/Nextel
telephones and pagers shall be issued only to those employees with a
demonstrated need for these types of communications. Cellular/Nextel telephones
and pagers shall be requested only by authorized personnel within departments.
Employees who use a Village issued cellular/Nextel telephone agree to the
following rules of use:
      (1)   Employees must reimburse the Village for any costs associated with
personal use. Personal use must be clearly incidental to business use. personal
use with associated charges must be reported to supervisors.
      (2)   Employees must safeguard any cellular/Nextel telephone and pager
equipment in their possession.
      (3)   The loss of any cellular/Nextel telephone or pager equipment shall
be reported to the employee's supervisor immediately. If theft is suspected,
the police should also be notified immediately.
      (4)   Employees shall exercise extreme caution when driving and talking
on a cellular/Nextel telephone. Unless utilizing a "hands-free" speakerphone
option, employees should stop their vehicle as soon as safety possible to use
cellular/Nextel phones.
      (5)   Employees shall limit all cellular/Nextel calls to no more than
eight minutes. Calls over eight minutes shall be documented and justification
will be required.
      (6)   When an employee no longer has a demonstrated need for the
cellular/Nextel telephone or pager, or when the employee terminates employment
with any Village department, that employee shall return any cellular/Nextel
phone and pager equipment to that department.
      (7)   Any employee who exceeds their monthly-allotted minutes and/or
package dollar amount shall be subject to an immediate audit for the previous
12-month period, if requested by the Mayor. Costs that are associated with
excessive and/or personal costs that are not reimbursed by the employee at the
time of the audit may be considered theft and will result in appropriate
corrective action. Employees may choose to purchase a second line for their
personal use.
      (8)   Repeated non-compliance with this policy and failure to remain
within allotted minutes, costs, etc., shall result in progressive discipline
and may result in loss of cellular/Nextel and/or paging equipment.
      (9)   Nextel unit users agree to contact other Nextel users by direct
connect a majority of the time, with only rare instances requiring Nextel
cellular to Nextel cellular connections.
(Ord. 2004-9-5. Passed 11-2-04)
250.24 COMPENSATION FOR FULL-TIME EMPLOYEES NOT IN A BARGAINING UNIT.
   (a)   All full-time employees of the Village, which are not in a bargaining
unit, shall be entitled to the following vacations, holidays, personal days and
birthdays.
      (1)   At the time or times agreeable to the Mayor, department heads and
the employee, the full-time employees are entitled to ten working days vacation
during the calendar year after his or her first year of continuous service,
eleven working days off after completing three years of service, twelve working
days off after completing four years of service, thirteen working days off
after completing five years of service, fourteen working days off after
completing six years of service, fifteen working days off after completing
years of service, sixteen working days off after completing eight years of
service, seventeen working days off after completing nine years of service,
eighteen working days off after completing ten years of service, nineteen
working days off after completing eleven years of service, twenty working days
off after completing twelve years of service, twenty-one working days off after
completing thirteen years of service, twenty-two working days off after
completing fourteen years of service, twenty-three working days off after
completing fifteen years of service, twenty-four working days off after
completing sixteen years of service, twenty-five working days off after
completing seventeen years of service, twenty-six working days off after
completing eighteen years of service, twenty-seven working days off after
completing nineteen years of service, twenty-eight working days off after
completing twenty years of service. In addition to the aforesaid vacation
period, each full-time employee shall be entitled to the following ten paid
holidays: New Year's Day, President's Day, Good Friday, Memorial Day,
Independence Day, Labor Day, Columbus Day, Veteran's Day, Thanksgiving Day,
Christmas Day and five personal days, one of which is to be said employee's
birthday, provided, however, that the personal day's off must be approved by
the department head and the department head's personal day's off must be
approved by the Mayor and further provided that an employee will use their
birthday and four personal days as "time off" prior to November 1st of said
year, unless employee's birthday is in November or December of said year.
Effective January 1, 2003, for all full time non-union employees, the personal
days will count toward time worked for the purpose of calculating overtime.
      (2)   The following personnel must take their holidays as time off:
department heads, including Chief of Police, Fire Chief, Street Commissioner,
Building Inspector, Recreation Director, Janitor-Jailer, Clerk of Courts,
Senior Clerk and Junior Clerk and clerical personnel.
   (b)   All full-time non-bargaining unit employees shall receive a one-time
bonus in the amount of seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). In addition to
the aforesaid bonus, all full-time non-bargaining unit employees shall receive
a wage increase of two percent retroactive to July 1, 2009 and shall also
receive an additional two percent wage increase effective July 1, 2010.
   (c)   All part-time employees shall receive a wage increase of two percent
retroactive to January 1, 2009 and shall receive an additional wage increase of
two percent effective July 1, 2010.
   (d)   The Village will provide each full-time non-bargaining unit employee
with hospitalization, dental, vision and life insurance coverage as selected by
the Village. Effective March 1, 2010, the hospitalization coverage will be the
SMP 2000/4000 Health Savings Account through Medical Mutual of Ohio. The
Village will contribute 100 percent of the annual deductible for each employee.
Employees covered by the hospitalization plan shall be required to pay fifty
dollars ($50.00) per month towards the premium. Said amount shall be a pre-tax
deduction for said payments.
(Ord. 2010-3-8. Passed 3-16-10.)
250.25 PERMANENT PART-TIME CATEGORY CREATED.
   (a)   The category of permanent part-time is hereby created.
   (b)   Permanent part-time shall be defined as, "part-time employment that is
to continue indefinitely and until either party wishes to sever the
relationship."
(Ord. 2010-4-7. Passed 5-4-10.)
